Subject: [sfraves] SRR: News - Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage 

Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1223/a02.html
Newshawk: http://www.journeyforjustice.org
Pubdate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003
Source: Sun-Sentinel (Fort Lauderdale, FL)
Copyright: 2003 Sun-Sentinel Company
Contact: letters@sun-sentinel.com
Website: http://www.sun-sentinel.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/159
Author: Ricardo Chavira Jr.,The Dallas Morning News
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/areas/mexico
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/youth.htm
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm

RAVES BECOME ALL THE RAGE

PACHUCA--Through the darkness, young people stumble along an uneven path
into the thick forest of Mineral del Chico, a national park 60 miles
northeast of Mexico City.

Flashes of neon-green and fuchsia-pink lights illuminate the rock- strewn
trail and the Technicolor hair and multiple piercings of the hipsters.
Police at the entrance to the trail frisk everyone who passes through, as
smoke from marijuana joints and the pyrotechnic machine waft through the
dense brush.

Suddenly, the trees give way to a gigantic pit, where 4,000 to 5,000 kids
sway to syncopated music booming from a DJ booth.

This is a rave; a phenomenon imported from Europe that in Mexico draws
legions of young psycheros.  They see themselves as modern hippies.  They
dance all night to "psycho-trance" music.  And they consume lots of drugs
such as ecstasy, LSD and amphetamines, police say.

"This is our Woodstock," said Fernando Cisneros Cruz, 17, of Mexico City.
"We're Mexico's counterculture.  We take psychedelic drugs and party
nonstop."

"We're out here in nature to celebrate peace, love, unity and respect,"
said Cruz, using the English words to form the acronym, PLUR, that
psycheros live by.

With the growing popularity of club drugs, Mexico has become both a
destination and a trans-shipment point for chemical substances, said an
agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration.

The rave scene arrived in Mexico in the early 1990s and quickly attracted
artists and intellectuals seeking a new way to party.  Today, raves make
up a sizable subculture of mostly lower- and middle-class psycheros who
shun drugs such as cocaine and heroin.

A seminal rave event occurred last year in Guadalajara, when police
arrested 40 youths.  Psycheros say authorities reacted harshly because
they saw that raves were quickly becoming a haven for drug users.

The raver's drug of choice is ecstasy, or MDMA --
methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a stimulant and mild hallucinogenic popular
in U.S.  nightclubs in the late 1980s and '90s.

"We're starting to see abuse of ecstasy, LSD and methamphetamine in
Mexico's metropolitan areas," said Dr.  Victor Manuel Guisa Cruz, general
director of the Juvenile Intervention Center, a national organization
funded by government grants and private benefactors.

"Consumption of methamphetamine and ecstasy has increased due to the
youths' lack of knowledge about the enormous danger they cause," said Dr.
Guido Belsasso, commissioner of Mexico's National Council Against
Addictions.

A new study from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has linked
ecstasy with permanent brain damage and Parkinson's-like symptoms in some
users.

Once imported mostly from Europe, MDMA is now being produced in Mexico,
said an agent from the attorney general's office, or PGR.

"But the quality isn't as good.  The pills are often mixed with
methamphetamine, PCP, or pharmaceuticals," said the agent, who asked that
his name not be used.

Today, ecstasy producers mark their pills with Asian lettering or
stenciled animals, such as scorpions, to build brand loyalty.

At the Mineral del Chico rave, dealers circulate freely, hawking their
wares over the deafening thumps of bass lines: "Ecstasy! Acid! Meth!"

Ravers dressed in ancient tribal wear, bleached-white tunics and glittery
1950s-style space suits routinely stop the dealers.

At 1 a.m., one dealer says he's almost sold out.  "I can barely keep up.
Everybody here wants to get high," said the teenager, clad in a long white
fur coat and matching white-rimmed sunglasses.

Dr.  Arturo Alvarado, a sociology professor at El Colegio de Mexico, in
part blames Mexico's sputtering economy for the growing drug use.

"Without an education or jobs, youths have a hard time integrating
themselves into society," he said.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 1:38 PM
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: News - Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage


Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1223/a02.html
Newshawk: http://www.journeyforjustice.org
Pubdate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003
Source: Sun-Sentinel (Fort Lauderdale, FL)
Copyright: 2003 Sun-Sentinel Company
Contact: letters@sun-sentinel.com
Website: http://www.sun-sentinel.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/159
Author: Ricardo Chavira Jr.,The Dallas Morning News
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/areas/mexico
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/youth.htm
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm

RAVES BECOME ALL THE RAGE

PACHUCA--Through the darkness, young people stumble along an uneven path
into the thick forest of Mineral del Chico, a national park 60 miles
northeast of Mexico City.

Flashes of neon-green and fuchsia-pink lights illuminate the rock- strewn
trail and the Technicolor hair and multiple piercings of the hipsters.
Police at the entrance to the trail frisk everyone who passes through, as
smoke from marijuana joints and the pyrotechnic machine waft through the
dense brush.

Suddenly, the trees give way to a gigantic pit, where 4,000 to 5,000 kids
sway to syncopated music booming from a DJ booth.

This is a rave; a phenomenon imported from Europe that in Mexico draws
legions of young psycheros.  They see themselves as modern hippies.  They
dance all night to "psycho-trance" music.  And they consume lots of drugs
such as ecstasy, LSD and amphetamines, police say.

"This is our Woodstock," said Fernando Cisneros Cruz, 17, of Mexico City.
"We're Mexico's counterculture.  We take psychedelic drugs and party
nonstop."

"We're out here in nature to celebrate peace, love, unity and respect,"
said Cruz, using the English words to form the acronym, PLUR, that
psycheros live by.

With the growing popularity of club drugs, Mexico has become both a
destination and a trans-shipment point for chemical substances, said an
agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration.

The rave scene arrived in Mexico in the early 1990s and quickly attracted
artists and intellectuals seeking a new way to party.  Today, raves make
up a sizable subculture of mostly lower- and middle-class psycheros who
shun drugs such as cocaine and heroin.

A seminal rave event occurred last year in Guadalajara, when police
arrested 40 youths.  Psycheros say authorities reacted harshly because
they saw that raves were quickly becoming a haven for drug users.

The raver's drug of choice is ecstasy, or MDMA --
methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a stimulant and mild hallucinogenic popular
in U.S.  nightclubs in the late 1980s and '90s.

"We're starting to see abuse of ecstasy, LSD and methamphetamine in
Mexico's metropolitan areas," said Dr.  Victor Manuel Guisa Cruz, general
director of the Juvenile Intervention Center, a national organization
funded by government grants and private benefactors.

"Consumption of methamphetamine and ecstasy has increased due to the
youths' lack of knowledge about the enormous danger they cause," said Dr.
Guido Belsasso, commissioner of Mexico's National Council Against
Addictions.

A new study from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has linked
ecstasy with permanent brain damage and Parkinson's-like symptoms in some
users.

Once imported mostly from Europe, MDMA is now being produced in Mexico,
said an agent from the attorney general's office, or PGR.

"But the quality isn't as good.  The pills are often mixed with
methamphetamine, PCP, or pharmaceuticals," said the agent, who asked that
his name not be used.

Today, ecstasy producers mark their pills with Asian lettering or
stenciled animals, such as scorpions, to build brand loyalty.

At the Mineral del Chico rave, dealers circulate freely, hawking their
wares over the deafening thumps of bass lines: "Ecstasy! Acid! Meth!"

Ravers dressed in ancient tribal wear, bleached-white tunics and glittery
1950s-style space suits routinely stop the dealers.

At 1 a.m., one dealer says he's almost sold out.  "I can barely keep up.
Everybody here wants to get high," said the teenager, clad in a long white
fur coat and matching white-rimmed sunglasses.

Dr.  Arturo Alvarado, a sociology professor at El Colegio de Mexico, in
part blames Mexico's sputtering economy for the growing drug use.

"Without an education or jobs, youths have a hard time integrating
themselves into society," he said.

the past week. (Before your post to me). Save your judgements for someone
else, your criticism is unwarranted and ridiculous.

**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************


On Thu, 21 Aug 2003, innocentchild wrote:

> You missed the previous thread on this article last week. I thought as a
> person that's involved with the behind the scenes of sfraves that you
would
> actually read the list too. Please read before you repost old news. (and
go
> look at last weeks archives to catch up on what you missed)
>
> ryan.bailey
> sninesix.design
> design :: www.sninesix.com
> photography :: www.innocentchild.com
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 1:38 PM
> Subject: [sfraves] SRR: News - Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
>
>
> Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
> URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1223/a02.html
> Newshawk: http://www.journeyforjustice.org
> Pubdate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003
> Source: Sun-Sentinel (Fort Lauderdale, FL)
> Copyright: 2003 Sun-Sentinel Company
> Contact: letters@sun-sentinel.com
> Website: http://www.sun-sentinel.com/
> Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/159
> Author: Ricardo Chavira Jr.,The Dallas Morning News
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/areas/mexico
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/youth.htm
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm
>
> RAVES BECOME ALL THE RAGE
>
> PACHUCA--Through the darkness, young people stumble along an uneven path
> into the thick forest of Mineral del Chico, a national park 60 miles
> northeast of Mexico City.
>
> Flashes of neon-green and fuchsia-pink lights illuminate the rock- strewn
> trail and the Technicolor hair and multiple piercings of the hipsters.
> Police at the entrance to the trail frisk everyone who passes through, as
> smoke from marijuana joints and the pyrotechnic machine waft through the
> dense brush.
>
> Suddenly, the trees give way to a gigantic pit, where 4,000 to 5,000 kids
> sway to syncopated music booming from a DJ booth.
>
> This is a rave; a phenomenon imported from Europe that in Mexico draws
> legions of young psycheros.  They see themselves as modern hippies.  They
> dance all night to "psycho-trance" music.  And they consume lots of drugs
> such as ecstasy, LSD and amphetamines, police say.
>
> "This is our Woodstock," said Fernando Cisneros Cruz, 17, of Mexico City.
> "We're Mexico's counterculture.  We take psychedelic drugs and party
> nonstop."
>
> "We're out here in nature to celebrate peace, love, unity and respect,"
> said Cruz, using the English words to form the acronym, PLUR, that
> psycheros live by.
>
> With the growing popularity of club drugs, Mexico has become both a
> destination and a trans-shipment point for chemical substances, said an
> agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration.
>
> The rave scene arrived in Mexico in the early 1990s and quickly attracted
> artists and intellectuals seeking a new way to party.  Today, raves make
> up a sizable subculture of mostly lower- and middle-class psycheros who
> shun drugs such as cocaine and heroin.
>
> A seminal rave event occurred last year in Guadalajara, when police
> arrested 40 youths.  Psycheros say authorities reacted harshly because
> they saw that raves were quickly becoming a haven for drug users.
>
> The raver's drug of choice is ecstasy, or MDMA --
> methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a stimulant and mild hallucinogenic popular
> in U.S.  nightclubs in the late 1980s and '90s.
>
> "We're starting to see abuse of ecstasy, LSD and methamphetamine in
> Mexico's metropolitan areas," said Dr.  Victor Manuel Guisa Cruz, general
> director of the Juvenile Intervention Center, a national organization
> funded by government grants and private benefactors.
>
> "Consumption of methamphetamine and ecstasy has increased due to the
> youths' lack of knowledge about the enormous danger they cause," said Dr.
> Guido Belsasso, commissioner of Mexico's National Council Against
> Addictions.
>
> A new study from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has linked
> ecstasy with permanent brain damage and Parkinson's-like symptoms in some
> users.
>
> Once imported mostly from Europe, MDMA is now being produced in Mexico,
> said an agent from the attorney general's office, or PGR.
>
> "But the quality isn't as good.  The pills are often mixed with
> methamphetamine, PCP, or pharmaceuticals," said the agent, who asked that
> his name not be used.
>
> Today, ecstasy producers mark their pills with Asian lettering or
> stenciled animals, such as scorpions, to build brand loyalty.
>
> At the Mineral del Chico rave, dealers circulate freely, hawking their
> wares over the deafening thumps of bass lines: "Ecstasy! Acid! Meth!"
>
> Ravers dressed in ancient tribal wear, bleached-white tunics and glittery
> 1950s-style space suits routinely stop the dealers.
>
> At 1 a.m., one dealer says he's almost sold out.  "I can barely keep up.
> Everybody here wants to get high," said the teenager, clad in a long white
> fur coat and matching white-rimmed sunglasses.
>
> Dr.  Arturo Alvarado, a sociology professor at El Colegio de Mexico, in
> part blames Mexico's sputtering economy for the growing drug use.
>
> "Without an education or jobs, youths have a hard time integrating
> themselves into society," he said.
>
>
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> **************************************************************

> > legions of young psycheros.  They see themselves as modern hippies.
They
> > dance all night to "psycho-trance" music.  And they consume lots of
drugs
> > such as ecstasy, LSD and amphetamines, police say.
> >
> > "This is our Woodstock," said Fernando Cisneros Cruz, 17, of Mexico
City.
> > "We're Mexico's counterculture.  We take psychedelic drugs and party
> > nonstop."
> >
> > "We're out here in nature to celebrate peace, love, unity and respect,"
> > said Cruz, using the English words to form the acronym, PLUR, that
> > psycheros live by.
> >
> > With the growing popularity of club drugs, Mexico has become both a
> > destination and a trans-shipment point for chemical substances, said an
> > agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration.
> >
> > The rave scene arrived in Mexico in the early 1990s and quickly
attracted
> > artists and intellectuals seeking a new way to party.  Today, raves make
> > up a sizable subculture of mostly lower- and middle-class psycheros who
> > shun drugs such as cocaine and heroin.
> >
> > A seminal rave event occurred last year in Guadalajara, when police
> > arrested 40 youths.  Psycheros say authorities reacted harshly because
> > they saw that raves were quickly becoming a haven for drug users.
> >
> > The raver's drug of choice is ecstasy, or MDMA --
> > methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a stimulant and mild hallucinogenic
popular
> > in U.S.  nightclubs in the late 1980s and '90s.
> >
> > "We're starting to see abuse of ecstasy, LSD and methamphetamine in
> > Mexico's metropolitan areas," said Dr.  Victor Manuel Guisa Cruz,
general
> > director of the Juvenile Intervention Center, a national organization
> > funded by government grants and private benefactors.
> >
> > "Consumption of methamphetamine and ecstasy has increased due to the
> > youths' lack of knowledge about the enormous danger they cause," said
Dr.
> > Guido Belsasso, commissioner of Mexico's National Council Against
> > Addictions.
> >
> > A new study from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has linked
> > ecstasy with permanent brain damage and Parkinson's-like symptoms in
some
> > users.
> >
> > Once imported mostly from Europe, MDMA is now being produced in Mexico,
> > said an agent from the attorney general's office, or PGR.
> >
> > "But the quality isn't as good.  The pills are often mixed with
> > methamphetamine, PCP, or pharmaceuticals," said the agent, who asked
that
> > his name not be used.
> >
> > Today, ecstasy producers mark their pills with Asian lettering or
> > stenciled animals, such as scorpions, to build brand loyalty.
> >
> > At the Mineral del Chico rave, dealers circulate freely, hawking their
> > wares over the deafening thumps of bass lines: "Ecstasy! Acid! Meth!"
> >
> > Ravers dressed in ancient tribal wear, bleached-white tunics and
glittery
> > 1950s-style space suits routinely stop the dealers.
> >
> > At 1 a.m., one dealer says he's almost sold out.  "I can barely keep up.
> > Everybody here wants to get high," said the teenager, clad in a long
white
> > fur coat and matching white-rimmed sunglasses.
> >
> > Dr.  Arturo Alvarado, a sociology professor at El Colegio de Mexico, in
> > part blames Mexico's sputtering economy for the growing drug use.
> >
> > "Without an education or jobs, youths have a hard time integrating
> > themselves into society," he said.
> >
> >
> > **************************************************************
> > ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> > If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> > much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> > & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> > -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> > **************************************************************

> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>
> > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 1:38 PM
> > Subject: [sfraves] SRR: News - Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
> >
> >
> > Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage
> > URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v03/n1223/a02.html
> > Newshawk: http://www.journeyforjustice.org
> > Pubdate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003
> > Source: Sun-Sentinel (Fort Lauderdale, FL)
> > Copyright: 2003 Sun-Sentinel Company
> > Contact: letters@sun-sentinel.com
> > Website: http://www.sun-sentinel.com/
> > Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/159
> > Author: Ricardo Chavira Jr.,The Dallas Morning News
> > Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/areas/mexico
> > Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/youth.htm
> > Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm
> >
> > RAVES BECOME ALL THE RAGE
> >
> > PACHUCA--Through the darkness, young people stumble along an uneven path
> > into the thick forest of Mineral del Chico, a national park 60 miles
> > northeast of Mexico City.
> >
> > Flashes of neon-green and fuchsia-pink lights illuminate the rock-
strewn
> > trail and the Technicolor hair and multiple piercings of the hipsters.
> > Police at the entrance to the trail frisk everyone who passes through,
as
> > smoke from marijuana joints and the pyrotechnic machine waft through the
> > dense brush.
> >
> > Suddenly, the trees give way to a gigantic pit, where 4,000 to 5,000
kids
> > sway to syncopated music booming from a DJ booth.
> >
> > This is a rave; a phenomenon imported from Europe that in Mexico draws
> > legions of young psycheros.  They see themselves as modern hippies.
They
> > dance all night to "psycho-trance" music.  And they consume lots of
drugs
> > such as ecstasy, LSD and amphetamines, police say.
> >
> > "This is our Woodstock," said Fernando Cisneros Cruz, 17, of Mexico
City.
> > "We're Mexico's counterculture.  We take psychedelic drugs and party
> > nonstop."
> >
> > "We're out here in nature to celebrate peace, love, unity and respect,"
> > said Cruz, using the English words to form the acronym, PLUR, that
> > psycheros live by.
> >
> > With the growing popularity of club drugs, Mexico has become both a
> > destination and a trans-shipment point for chemical substances, said an
> > agent for the Drug Enforcement Administration.
> >
> > The rave scene arrived in Mexico in the early 1990s and quickly
attracted
> > artists and intellectuals seeking a new way to party.  Today, raves make
> > up a sizable subculture of mostly lower- and middle-class psycheros who
> > shun drugs such as cocaine and heroin.
> >
> > A seminal rave event occurred last year in Guadalajara, when police
> > arrested 40 youths.  Psycheros say authorities reacted harshly because
> > they saw that raves were quickly becoming a haven for drug users.
> >
> > The raver's drug of choice is ecstasy, or MDMA --
> > methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a stimulant and mild hallucinogenic
popular
> > in U.S.  nightclubs in the late 1980s and '90s.
> >
> > "We're starting to see abuse of ecstasy, LSD and methamphetamine in
> > Mexico's metropolitan areas," said Dr.  Victor Manuel Guisa Cruz,
general
> > director of the Juvenile Intervention Center, a national organization
> > funded by government grants and private benefactors.
> >
> > "Consumption of methamphetamine and ecstasy has increased due to the
> > youths' lack of knowledge about the enormous danger they cause," said
Dr.
> > Guido Belsasso, commissioner of Mexico's National Council Against
> > Addictions.
> >
> > A new study from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has linked
> > ecstasy with permanent brain damage and Parkinson's-like symptoms in
some
> > users.
> >
> > Once imported mostly from Europe, MDMA is now being produced in Mexico,
> > said an agent from the attorney general's office, or PGR.
> >
> > "But the quality isn't as good.  The pills are often mixed with
> > methamphetamine, PCP, or pharmaceuticals," said the agent, who asked
that
> > his name not be used.
> >
> > Today, ecstasy producers mark their pills with Asian lettering or
> > stenciled animals, such as scorpions, to build brand loyalty.
> >
> > At the Mineral del Chico rave, dealers circulate freely, hawking their
> > wares over the deafening thumps of bass lines: "Ecstasy! Acid! Meth!"
> >
> > Ravers dressed in ancient tribal wear, bleached-white tunics and
glittery
> > 1950s-style space suits routinely stop the dealers.
> >
> > At 1 a.m., one dealer says he's almost sold out.  "I can barely keep up.
> > Everybody here wants to get high," said the teenager, clad in a long
white
> > fur coat and matching white-rimmed sunglasses.
> >
> > Dr.  Arturo Alvarado, a sociology professor at El Colegio de Mexico, in
> > part blames Mexico's sputtering economy for the growing drug use.
> >
> > "Without an education or jobs, youths have a hard time integrating
> > themselves into society," he said.
> >
> >
> > **************************************************************
> > ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************

Subject: [sfraves] STOP RAVE ACT II

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

STOP RAVE ACT II

Your Right to Dance Is Under Attack - Again!

Take Action at: 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=11060

Earlier this year, backdoor politics led to the passage of the RAVE Act, a 
law that makes it easier for law enforcement to arrest event holders for 
the drug offenses of their patrons. Now, Congress is at it again. Under the 
Ecstasy Awareness Act live entertainment will receive another threatening 
blow. Your rights are in danger, take action now!!

Already the RAVE Act has been used to intimidate promoters of festivals and 
political fund raisers into calling off their events. Like the RAVE Act, 
the Ecstasy Awareness Act, could effectively ban live music and dancing 
while throwing innocent people like you in jail. In light of the fact that 
drug use is a probable occurrence at any musical event, HR 2962 opens the 
door for any concert promoter, event organizer, or nightclub owner to be 
fined and jailed. It doesn't matter if they tried to prevent people from 
using drugs. Nor does it matter if the vast majority of people attending 
the event are law-abiding citizens that want to listen to music and not do 
drugs.

The Ecstasy Awareness Act of 2003 is another dangerous piece of legislation 
that could prevent you from seeing your favorite band or DJ live! It is 
vital that voters contact their Representatives and tell them not to 
co-sponsor this bill.

Actions to Take:

** Fax your Representative today. To find our more go to
    http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=11060 .

** Forward this alert to your friends, family, and co-workers.

For more information on this bill, go to http://thomas.loc.gov/ and under 
"bill number" search for HR2962.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_1680708==.ALT--

Or check out:

ROAR!
THE NATIONAL DANCE AND MUSIC RIGHTS ALLIANCE
WWW.ROARGROUP.ORG

::POWER TO THE PEOPLE WHO PARTY::

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 2003
NOON TO MIDNIGHT
DEMONSTRATION AT THE US CAPITOL
AGAINST ANTI-MUSIC LAWS

THE RAVE ACT HAS PASSED!

Just because you're paranoid doesn't mean everyone's not out to get you.

It's been a crazy couple of years for the Electronic Dance Music scene. On
top
of the last decade of being targeted with raids, arrests, harassment,
intimidation and smear campaigns, last summer saw the introduction of the
now-
infamous RAVE Act. Passed in the spring, the law can fine promoters,
managers,
or employees up to $500,000 and/or imprison them for 20 years for holding an
event where even a single person is arrested for narcotics--potentially
shutting down events everywhere. This year, we are facing the CLEAN-UP Act
and
the Ecstasy Awareness Act, both of which would impose far harsher penalties.

Last summer, well over a thousans descended US Capitol for ROAR! and
America's
first ever party-as-protest. Other events have popped up in cities all over
the
country--Seattle, NYC, LA, SF, Austin, Albequerque to name a few--marking
the
start of an entire movement and bringing a whole generation to power.

This summer join ROAR! and let's bring thousands to the US Capitol for a
free
outdoor festival and protest against the continuing assault on music,
dancing
and civil liberties. We will display the force and unity of our culture
through
performances by international headlining talent, speakers from major
industry
groups and politically influential organizations.


EVENT INFORMATION

UPPER SENATE PARK, US CAPITOL, WASHINGTON, DC
Constitution Ave between New Jersey NW and Delaware Ave NE

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 6:53 PM
Subject: [sfraves] STOP RAVE ACT II


> STOP RAVE ACT II
>
> Your Right to Dance Is Under Attack - Again!
>
> Take Action at:
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=11060
>
> Earlier this year, backdoor politics led to the passage of the RAVE Act, a
> law that makes it easier for law enforcement to arrest event holders for
> the drug offenses of their patrons. Now, Congress is at it again. Under
the
> Ecstasy Awareness Act live entertainment will receive another threatening
> blow. Your rights are in danger, take action now!!
>
> Already the RAVE Act has been used to intimidate promoters of festivals
and
> political fund raisers into calling off their events. Like the RAVE Act,
> the Ecstasy Awareness Act, could effectively ban live music and dancing
> while throwing innocent people like you in jail. In light of the fact that
> drug use is a probable occurrence at any musical event, HR 2962 opens the
> door for any concert promoter, event organizer, or nightclub owner to be
> fined and jailed. It doesn't matter if they tried to prevent people from
> using drugs. Nor does it matter if the vast majority of people attending
> the event are law-abiding citizens that want to listen to music and not do
> drugs.
>
> The Ecstasy Awareness Act of 2003 is another dangerous piece of
legislation
> that could prevent you from seeing your favorite band or DJ live! It is
> vital that voters contact their Representatives and tell them not to
> co-sponsor this bill.
>
> Actions to Take:
>
> ** Fax your Representative today. To find our more go to
>     http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=11060
.
>
> ** Forward this alert to your friends, family, and co-workers.
>
> For more information on this bill, go to http://thomas.loc.gov/ and under
> "bill number" search for HR2962.
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
>
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
It's
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well
can
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when
we
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron
>
> "It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
> -Dizzy Gillespie

From: JonnyR@aol.com
To: karina@hyperreal.org, innocentchild@hotmail.com

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-AOL-IP: 168.103.98.161

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: News - Mexico: Raves Become All The Rage

ok, obviously there is some bad blood here but I don't think  the entire SFR community has to keep hearing about it. We're making a massive out of a molehill. 

Is it such a big deal if someone posts something that's already been posted? Is it so hard to just delete it? Maybe if people have an ongoing dispute, they can roll up their sleeves and take it off line. 

All right, go ahead and say I'm naive, but at my first rave, somebody explained PLUR to me. I figure some of you people have been into the rave thing so long that you've forgotten, or maybe could use a little reminder. 

P for Peace. This isn't worth fighting over! 

L for Love. ok, probably no love forthcoming between the adversarial parties, but maybe some ability to at least Let It Be. 

U for Unity. We probably all have a lot in common and it's silly to be fighting each other when we have real enemies (e.g., Ashcroft, adverse court decisions, and people who charge too much for bottled water...)

R is for Respect. There's no need to get personal and insulting when disagreeing with people. We are not a homogeneous subculture (No! I'm not talking about cultures in homogenized yogurt hehe) so we should expect differences in perspective. It's rude to flame people on message boards, even if there's a smiley face in the sentence.

(I've heard of an enhanced version of PLUR called SLURP but that's for another post!)
Sorry if I seem like a do-gooder trying to break up fights. I just don't like aggression.
John

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

The drive was peaceful at 4:30 am. =A0I10 never seemed so clear. =A0I headed=
 west=20
toward Santa Monica. =A0I rolled my windows down to feel the brisk ocean=20
breeze. =A0A cool, humid sting engulfed me casting goosebumps. =A0I panned a=
round the=20
scenery doing 70mph, glancing at the downtown skyline. =A0Massive edifices o=
ddly=20
lit up like christmas trees in the midst of a summer night. =A0Behind me a f=
aint=20
orange glow emminated behind the morning clouds. =A0Ahead of me a dark prese=
nce=20
awaited, the "end of the world" some people call it. =A0I couldn't see it, b=
ut I=20
knew the ocean was there hiding, waiting to surprise the city at the birth o=
f=20
a brand new day. I never thought such poetry and beauty could be found withi=
n=20
the confines of city valleys, but here it was, hidden in 4:30 am.=20

This reminds me of a Dilbert strip I saw a while back.

Dogbert has decided to infiltrate management for some reason.  And in order to
do so, he basiclly just screams at the execs: "I AM A LOUD DOG!  GIVE ME A JOB!
 WITH STOCK OPTIONS!  (Did I mentiom that this was an OLD Dilbert?).  I WANT A
COMPANY CAR!".  And he got everything he wanted just by loudly demanding it.

Come to think of it, maybe I SHOULD try this approach.  It can't work any worse
than what I've been doing otherwise.  (The traditional approach... Resume on
the 'net, mailing it out, dressing nice for interviews, and so on.)

No actual comparison is intended between anyone on SFRaves and any dog, comic
or otherwise, BTW.  This thread just made me remember that particular episode.


cya,

Subject: [sfraves] "DETROIT" this Sunday @ the Skylark

--0-1637321373-1061573830=:84186
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

"DETROIT" - our experiment in culture transplantation and mixup, continues this week - this Sunday night at the Skylark. 
 
Opening up, DJ 12 Mile, moonlighting from his drummer gig in Pirate Radio, will rock the D's rawkus garage noize and irresistable Motown charms of old.  Later, Baby Daddy will hop on the decks and whirl out a bpm ranging hot mixx across other side of Detroit's soundscape (that is... distinctive hip hop, proper techno, the deepest house, electro neuroses, new school IDM, and ghetto freak festivity).
 
As always, the inventive bar staff at the Skylark will conjure up their own mixes to insure your Monday morning hangover is well worth it.

The Skylark is located at 3089 16th St. at Valencia, San Francisco.  
 
See ya Sunday!
 
~ the Woodward Posse ~

Message-ID: <54529.63.103.66.57.1061577993.squirrel@mail.kartre.net>
Date: Fri, 22 Aug 2003 11:46:33 -0700 (PDT)

X-Priority: 3

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Music for the Ride to the Party and the Ride Home

A week ago a friend asked me if I could throw together a mix for a friend
of his to whom he wanted to expose some new music.  He e-mailed me the
list of tracks he wanted, I added some of my own, and digitally mixed it
with MP3s (since I have only a couple of the tracks on vinyl).  The result
was a decent chillout/mellow club/trance compilation, that seems suitable
for the ride to the party tonight or the ride home tomorrow morning.  ;)

http://www.deciblast.org/forums/dload.php?action=file&file_id=3

The tracklist is within that link as well.  There's even a cue file so you
don't have to fast forward through one 80-minute track...

http://www.kartre.net/audio/digital.cue

Hope ya like it.  =)

C.
AIM : Epsilon CN

Subject: Re: [sfraves]DJs: Loose mixer knobs? NRR


a supersmall shred of kleenex/tp4yorbunghol *does* work.  figure about a
3/8" by 1/8"  piece, draped over the top of the inner black plastic.
then, push the knob on, with about ten pounds of force.  if it doesn't go
on, try a little bit less.  it'll just pop on, and your woes will be over.

andyw

andyw    -   mutorsoundsystem   -    saturn5.com/andy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How bout this

I forget if I've done this on the Hyperreal list yet, but each month
(starting in, uh, August, LOL) I'm trying to post a "Top 7 + 3" list of my
seven favorite current trance tracks and three older ones I've
"rediscovered"... these three may be old hat to some veterans, but they're
either forgotten by or new to me.

Here was the last batch:

Top 7 Current Favorites

Mike Shiver - Feelings (Rusch & Murray Mix) [Lost Language]
Karada - Last Flight (Robert Nickson Mix) [Lost Language]
Mesh - Esthetic Visions [In Trance We Trust]
Pulser - My Religion [Godskitchen]
Misja Helsloot - First Second (Signum Mix) [First Second]
Rah - Wave (Airbase Mix) [Platipus Euro]
Iio - At the End (Ultrasun Mix) [Made]

Top 3 Rediscovered Treasures

Art of Trance - Octopus (Man with No Name Mix) [Platipus]
Vicious Circles - Vicious Circles (Max Graham Mix) [Platipus]
Christopher Lawrence - Shredder (Transa Mix) [Hook]

If you go to http://www.deciblast.org/~epsilon/ you can hear sound samples
for most of the top 7.  Of course all ten can probably be found on
SoulSeek or some other file-sharing service.

You should also check out the forum at http://www.tranceaddict.com. 
There've been a couple threads on there about "Top 100 Trance Tunes" or
"Best Trance from 1992 to 2000".

I'm not too educated about other genres, but there are plenty of people on
the list who are.  =)

C.
AIM : Epsilon CN

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Virus News

--=====================_12012729==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

 From the Speakeasy network:

We are writing to inform all of our customers running Microsoft
IIS, Microsoft Windows 2000 or XP operating systems of a recent
viral threat to the Internet. If you do not have any computers
running Microsoft IIS or either of these operating systems, you
may disregard this alert.

The most recent virus threat to the Internet, W32.Welchia.Worm,
also known as, W32/Welchia.worm10240 [AhnLab], W32/Nachi.worm
[McAfee], WORM_MSBLAST.D [Trend], Lovsan.D [F-Secure],
W32/Nachi-A [Sophos], Win32.Nachi.A [CA], Worm.Win32.Welchia
[KAV], has been upgraded by Symantec to a Category 4 (of 5)
threat.

This worm attempts to download the DCOM RPC patch from Microsoft
Windows Update Web site, install it, and then reboot the
computer. It then checks for active machines to infect by sending
echo requests, or PING requests, which will result in increased
ICMP traffic.

The worm also attempts to remove the W32.Blaster.Worm.

For further detail regarding this worm, please visit:

Symantec:
http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.worm.html

McAfee:
http://us.mcafee.com/virusInfo/default.asp?id=description&virus_k=100559

To remove this worm from your system, please visit:

http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.worm.removal.tool.html

Note that if you use McAfee software, removal instructions are on the
indicated page.

Additionally, we ask that you run a full 'Microsoft Update' to
ensure your machine is fully protected from this worm and any
other security concerns.  It will be necessary to reboot all
machines that are patched and updated, otherwise the updates will
not take affect.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

Cartman <carter@kartre.net> wrote:I forget if I've done this on the Hyperreal list yet, but each month
(starting in, uh, August, LOL) I'm trying to post a "Top 7 + 3" list of my
seven favorite current trance tracks and three older ones I've
"rediscovered"... these three may be old hat to some veterans, but they're
either forgotten by or new to me.

Here was the last batch:

Top 7 Current Favorites

Mike Shiver - Feelings (Rusch & Murray Mix) [Lost Language]
Karada - Last Flight (Robert Nickson Mix) [Lost Language]
Mesh - Esthetic Visions [In Trance We Trust]
Pulser - My Religion [Godskitchen]
Misja Helsloot - First Second (Signum Mix) [First Second]
Rah - Wave (Airbase Mix) [Platipus Euro]
Iio - At the End (Ultrasun Mix) [Made]

Top 3 Rediscovered Treasures

Art of Trance - Octopus (Man with No Name Mix) [Platipus]
Vicious Circles - Vicious Circles (Max Graham Mix) [Platipus]
Christopher Lawrence - Shredder (Transa Mix) [Hook]

If you go to http://www.deciblast.org/~epsilon/ you can hear sound samples
for most of the top 7. Of course all ten can probably be found on
SoulSeek or some other file-sharing service.

You should also check out the forum at http://www.tranceaddict.com. 
There've been a couple threads on there about "Top 100 Trance Tunes" or
"Best Trance from 1992 to 2000".

I'm not too educated about other genres, but there are plenty of people on
the list who are. =)

C.
AIM : Epsilon CN

> Sincerely,

Subject: [sfraves] Rah Rah Rah (was re: How bout this)

The story I heard was "Wave" -- or maybe it was the A-side "Glow" -- was
actually intended to be a remix of Moogwai's "Neon", an awesome track in
its own right.  The remix sounded so different that it didn't make it onto
either of the two Platipus releases of "Neon", but was good enough to
merit its own release on Platipus Euro.

It's goofy that the tracks on that Rah record are credited as the "Airbase
Remix" and "Original Airbase Mix" since Rah and Airbase are aliases for
the same guy.  LOL.

And speaking of Platipus, I just got the newest Plati pressing: Greg
Murray's "I Feel Loved".  Definitely going to be in my September Top 7. 
=P

C.
AIM : Epsilon CN

Dear Gods man..  Who pissed in your cheerios?

Yeah, I know what it was..  It was sent to me as a play on the anti rave
sentiment of our government.

And trust me..  yeah, I know what music is, I know what Electronic music
is..  And Im sure since your "countercultured" you happen to know I work and
participate in and around most counter/underground/what-have-you culture as
is.  But then again you may just be spouting off in ignorance..  but hey ..
thats ok.. thats your right as an American Citizen, and I fight for peoples
rights..  so go for it :-)

And just because I go by the kandyman name doesnt mean you can play me off
as a stereotype.

Anyways.. on another subject.  Hope everyone has fun next week.. Im off to
burningman.. then chillits, then the DPA conference in New Jersey..  For
that matter..  the Harm Reduction Colalition is holding their conference in
New Orleans next year.. that ought to be a trip.

To everyone else, sorry for the mini rant.. this just caught me off guard,
and Im due my one "rabid response to a flame" per year.

I promise I wont do it again till next year :-)

See you on the playa (Im at the Pancake Playhouse this year.. FREE pancakes
every morning!)

-Bry

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: It happened to me [was: Virus News]

Yes, my work computer (Toshiba Tecra laptop running Windows 2000 Professional)
got infected and it died. All data is lost. I am screwed. Hope I can recover
some data from the network shared drives. The problem is that I don't think I
saved everything. (lesson learned, again) 

I really think that backing up should be easier than it is in real life (i.e.
faster) Users would do it frequently. We all know better, but sometimes we don't
take the time to save off data in another location.

Backing up is even more important now with these rampant computer problems.

At least all of my email is archived for me on an MS Exchange server. Work email
is such a vital source of information for technical writers. Now I can spend the
rest of the day recovering my subject matter expert threads.

Boy, I really need to dance now.


Greg  VP
>  From the Speakeasy network:
> 
> We are writing to inform all of our customers running Microsoft
> IIS, Microsoft Windows 2000 or XP operating systems of a recent
> viral threat to the Internet. If you do not have any computers
> running Microsoft IIS or either of these operating systems, you
> may disregard this alert.
> 
> The most recent virus threat to the Internet, W32.Welchia.Worm,
> also known as, W32/Welchia.worm10240 [AhnLab], W32/Nachi.worm
> [McAfee], WORM_MSBLAST.D [Trend], Lovsan.D [F-Secure],
> W32/Nachi-A [Sophos], Win32.Nachi.A [CA], Worm.Win32.Welchia
> [KAV], has been upgraded by Symantec to a Category 4 (of 5)
> threat.
> 
> This worm attempts to download the DCOM RPC patch from Microsoft
> Windows Update Web site, install it, and then reboot the
> computer. It then checks for active machines to infect by sending
> echo requests, or PING requests, which will result in increased
> ICMP traffic.
> 
> The worm also attempts to remove the W32.Blaster.Worm.
> 
> For further detail regarding this worm, please visit:

> 
> Symantec:
> http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.worm.html
> 
> McAfee:
> http://us.mcafee.com/virusInfo/default.asp?id=description&virus_k=100559
> 
> To remove this worm from your system, please visit:
> 
> http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.worm.removal
> .tool.html
> 
> Note that if you use McAfee software, removal instructions are on the
> indicated page.
> 
> Additionally, we ask that you run a full 'Microsoft Update' to
> ensure your machine is fully protected from this worm and any
> other security concerns.  It will be necessary to reboot all
> machines that are patched and updated, otherwise the updates will
> not take affect.
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
> 
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
> 
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can

> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: It happened to me [was: Virus News]

If a company can't spend the money on an automated backup system, one of
your IT guys should be able to write a simple VBS script or batch file
that backs up certain folders to a network user share just by
double-clicking on it with all your data and applications closed.
That's what we do here since its like pulling teeth to get anything
approved to purchase.  The network share should be backed up to tape as
well.  All servers should ;)

Wait, do you work at Comcast?  Or is that your personal email.  If
comcast I'm seriously surprised you don't have a backup solution.

-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: gregvp@comcast.net [mailto:gregvp@comcast.net] 
Sent: Friday, August 22, 2003 3:04 PM
To: Apollo
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: It happened to me [was: Virus News]


Yes, my work computer (Toshiba Tecra laptop running Windows 2000
Professional) got infected and it died. All data is lost. I am screwed.
Hope I can recover some data from the network shared drives. The problem
is that I don't think I saved everything. (lesson learned, again) 

I really think that backing up should be easier than it is in real life
(i.e.
faster) Users would do it frequently. We all know better, but sometimes
we don't take the time to save off data in another location.

Backing up is even more important now with these rampant computer
problems.

At least all of my email is archived for me on an MS Exchange server.
Work email is such a vital source of information for technical writers.
Now I can spend the rest of the day recovering my subject matter expert
threads.

Boy, I really need to dance now.


Greg  VP
>  From the Speakeasy network:
> 
> We are writing to inform all of our customers running Microsoft IIS, 
> Microsoft Windows 2000 or XP operating systems of a recent viral 
> threat to the Internet. If you do not have any computers running 
> Microsoft IIS or either of these operating systems, you may disregard 
> this alert.
> 
> The most recent virus threat to the Internet, W32.Welchia.Worm, also 
> known as, W32/Welchia.worm10240 [AhnLab], W32/Nachi.worm [McAfee], 
> WORM_MSBLAST.D [Trend], Lovsan.D [F-Secure], W32/Nachi-A [Sophos], 
> Win32.Nachi.A [CA], Worm.Win32.Welchia [KAV], has been upgraded by 
> Symantec to a Category 4 (of 5) threat.
> 
> This worm attempts to download the DCOM RPC patch from Microsoft 
> Windows Update Web site, install it, and then reboot the computer. It 
> then checks for active machines to infect by sending echo requests, or

> PING requests, which will result in increased ICMP traffic.
> 
> The worm also attempts to remove the W32.Blaster.Worm.
> 
> For further detail regarding this worm, please visit:

> 
> Symantec: 
> http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.wo
> rm.html
> 
> McAfee: 
> http://us.mcafee.com/virusInfo/default.asp?id=description&virus_k=1005
> 59
> 
> To remove this worm from your system, please visit:
> 
> http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.welchia.wo
> rm.removal
> .tool.html
> 
> Note that if you use McAfee software, removal instructions are on the 
> indicated page.
> 
> Additionally, we ask that you run a full 'Microsoft Update' to ensure 
> your machine is fully protected from this worm and any other security 
> concerns.  It will be necessary to reboot all machines that are 
> patched and updated, otherwise the updates will not take affect.
> 
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
> 
> House Music 101:  
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor 
> do
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is
no 
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring

> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
> 
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.

> It's
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness
well can 
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real
when we 
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron

> "It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
> -Dizzy Gillespie

And finally, Mister Nathan Seven (if that *is* your real name), I'd like
to thank you for using Opera to *download* my set rather than stream it.
A couple people have tried to stream it using WinAmp... why?  Just go
ahead and download it (for all you virus carrying windows users -> right
click on the link and save link to disk).  Better on server, better on
you.  That way if it sucks you delete it, but if it doesn't you don't have
to download it again... and playback doesn't rely on network conditions at
every point between my webserver and your box.

andyw

created for 8 channel ambisonic panning on the Sol System array at BM. If 
you are heading out there we will have by far the largest system there 
(www.solsystem.org); north east corner of the map. I will be heading up 
spatialization M-W using my software among other tools. It will be fucking 
mind blowing.  I go on 2:30am early Thursday morning.

The BManPanner uses parametric paths to create trajectories that can be 
automated. It sounds really kick ass.. I could go on and explain the 
details for days, but there really is nothing else out there that I have 
found like this in regard to commercial software..  woooo... The 3rd panner 
(red one) is for the ladies! Parametric equations are a turn on, right?

Ok.. Bye..

Saturday, August 23, 2003 ** Clockwork presents... 5th Annual *ATLANTiS*
**

STAGE 1 (FunkyHouse/TechHouse):  JUNiOR SANCHEZ (cube/armed/nyc), RICHARD
"HUMPTY" VISSION (MTV/Powertools/LA), HATIRAS
(defected/ihr/hatiras.com/toronto), DAVID GARCiA (moonshine/Ihr/solmatic),
RON REESER (djronreeser.com/terratraxx/solmatic), JOEY MAZZOLA (solmatic),
RICK V. (Inthamix/sac)

STAGE 2 (Trance/Progressive):  DEEPSKY (kinetic records/la), MARS
(frequency8.com/sf), ST. JOHN (housenation/wild 94.9/sf), TOM SLIK &
DYLOOT (skills/berkley), DENiSE (djdenise.com/sound asylum/sf), DRAGNFLY
(shaolin/lovetribe/sac).

STAGE 3 (HipHop/Jungle/Turntablism) Hosted by: Kevy Kev (the drum/kzsu
stanford)  BEATNUTS (N.Y.C), LIVING LEGENDS (LA), THE MYSTICS (LA),
DISFLEX6, DANNY THA WiLDCHILD (chicagojunglist/fullysorted/chicago), JUJU
(phuturo/advanced/renegade/uk), HAVOC w/ MC DUH (compression/sf), BICOLAS
& B DUB (skills junglist).

STAGE 4: (Local Showcase) HUEY, JASEN CHAVEZ, MATT FROST, FELIPE AVELAR,
RECKLESS RYAN, DJ HOPE, DJ TORQUE, JESSE GONZALEZ, DJ ELZ, SERG ROCKWELL,
RXFX, JORDAN JOVES, BILLY SOUL, DAVID OCHOA, ADAM SANTANA.

STAGE 5: (BR Productions)
 DOCTOR ROSS & DJ CARLOZ, THE DOCTOR, VALERIE SPARKS, JAXX THE RIPPER
CARLOS ALFONSO, JAMES DUB, JMARR, DOZA, LIQUID, DARCLEX.

BUY TICKETS ONLINE Tickets also available @ www.GrooveTickets.com Online
Ticket Holders will be granted exclusive line access for easy entry.

Silicon Valley's premiere psychedelic trance night continues to bring
top-notch psychedelic trance to Santa Clara on the 4th Monday of every
month. version three.eight: RANDOM (Phoenix Family) VAILIXI (Ataraxia)

be grills onsite for those that want to BBQ--make sure to bring the
charcoal and burgers! RCP West is also collecting school supplies and new
or used school age clothing (in good condition) to benefit those in need
as school nears. We feel that this is a small but important gesture that
we can make to help insure that the children in this area have what they
need to go to school this year with confidence.

Subject: [sfraves] .: [)!RT[30>< is l33t!


...or summin like that.

Aight email massif, we've got another sick night of junglistic goodness
comin' at you tonight.  It's so fan-fucking-tastic that we can't even tell
ya exactly what's going on, except for the fact that there'll be phat
beats and such.  Mantis Sound might be out... but they might not.  We
might play polka house... but we might not.  We might get silly crunk and
waffle at the end of the show... but... ok yeah we'll most likely do that.

go without your weekly dose of the 'box.  Runnin' from 7pm 'til
when-the-fuck-ever AM (eastern standard, of course), we'll be holdin' down
the fort on Jungletrain.net (just in case ya forgot!).  Here are some
links for your fine dining experience:

Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Losing the War on Terror

Losing the War on Terror
by David Wiggins 

There you have it. There is no longer any doubt 
whether the Bush administration's actions are 
having an impact on terrorist activity. They 
are having a definite impact. They are 
increasing terror. Bottom line: No one truck 
bombed the UN compound in Iraq when Saddam 
Hussein was in charge. 

We have Jordanian Embassy bombings, oil and 
water pipeline explosions, SAM missile potshots 
at airliners in Kenya and SAM missile salesmen 
in the USA, attacks on peacekeepers in 
Afghanistan, suicide bombings in Israel, Bali, 
and Saudi Arabia, a rejuvenated Taliban, a 
nuclear North Korea, a nuclear Iran, Osama bin 
Laden on the loose, Saddam Hussein on the 
loose, and the USA in 4th place on the world 
terror hit list.

What is Bush's response to all of this? Losing 
is winning. You see, the more it looks like we 
are losing - bombs and explosions, incinerated 
Humvees, dead soldiers and civilians, debt, 
deficit, drugs, etc., the more we are actually 
winning. It's all very simple to Dubya. Getting 
our asses kicked is a sign of progress. It is a 
sign of "desperation" on the part of the "dead-
enders". On August 19th, referring to the attack 
on the UN complex in Baghdad, Bush said:
"Every sign of progress in Iraq adds to the 
desperation of the terrorists and the remnants 
of Saddam's brutal regime." 

You know the dead-enders. They are the "give me 
liberty or give me death" crowd. They have this 
silly idea that if they keep using irregular 
tactics against their occupiers, they might 
actually defeat King George... uh, I mean... 
President George Bush. 

Bush and Blair lies to the contrary, it is now 
clear that US and British intelligence services 
as well as any other intelligence services they 
cared to ask knew that Al-Qaeda had little or 
no presence in Iraq before the US invasion. 
Saddam Hussein made sure of that. He didn't 
want any competition. The only Islamist group 
in Iraq at all, Ansar-al-Islam, was confined to 
a small remote corner of northern Iraq. Saddam 
Hussein could not get at them there because the 
area was under the protection of the United 
States via its unsanctioned "Northern No Fly 
Zone."

Now we see that the US invasion of Iraq is the 
best thing that ever happened to Ansar-al-
Islam. Paul Bremer, the US civilian 
administrator in Iraq, said there was, "clear 
evidence of an Al-Qaeda-related terrorist 
group, the Ansar al-Islam, reconstituting its 
capabilities inside of Iraq since the war". The 
group is now operating all over Iraq. It is 
suspected in the bombing of the Jordanian 
Embassy in Baghdad on august 7th. The Al-Qaeda 
recruiters haven't had it so good since the 
Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. A recently 
released message to the Al-Qaeda troops exhorts 
them to go to Iraq to kill Americans. But this 
is all good news to the Bush Administration. It 
just shows how desperate all those terrorists 
are. "Bring them on!" says George. I'll bet the 
UN personnel really appreciate that.

In Afghanistan, the Taliban seem very 
desperate. In case no one noticed, those dead-
enders are making more comebacks than Freddy 
Krueger. Last week witnessed the bloodiest week 
in Afghanistan since the US invasion of that 
country, with over 100 dead due to bus 
bombings, rocket attacks, clashes with Taliban 
militants, and between rival militias in 
southern and southeastern Afghanistan. 

Remember George Bush telling us that the drug 
trade was a major source of financing for 
terrorism? It is a sign of how desperate things 
are in Afghanistan that the production of opium 
for heroin is up to its highest levels ever. 
Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld called the 
production of opium in Afghanistan a "whale of 
a problem." The country now is the largest 
opium producer in the world - and to think that 
the Taliban had essentially eliminated opium 
production in Afghanistan. Now that is 
desperation! Given President Bush's losing is 
winning philosophy; Afghanistan is a two-bagger 
because there, we seem to be losing both the 
"War on Terror" and the "War on Drugs." Opium 
production is up in Colombia too. 

Representative Henry Hyde states that opium 
production in Colombia has revived. It 
supplies, he stated, ''more than 60 percent of 
U.S. heroin.'' George Bush, of course, would 
say that all this just shows how desperate the 
terrorists and opium producers are for money. 

Osama Bin Laden must be very desperate. He 
keeps sending out inspirational messages to his 
mujahadeen. On August 18th he exhorted the 
mujahadeen to go to Iraq to fight US forces. On 
the 19th he claimed responsibility for the 
largest blackout in US history. President Bush 
says we'll "smoke him out". Osama must have an 
incredible tolerance for smoke. We have been 
"smoking" for almost two years now. Producing 
all that smoke, no wonder the Bush 
administration is opposed to the Global Warming 
Treaty. But not only are we "smoking him out," 
we are "tightening the noose" around Osama's 
neck. I wonder if there is a Guinness Book of 
World Records entry for "world's largest noose" 
or perhaps, "worlds slowest tightening noose." 
George must be ecstatic about the desperation 
shown by the terrorists on the home front. 

According to the London-based World Markets 
Research Center, the US is the 4th most likely 
nation to experience a terrorist attack. Of 186 
nations, we come in behind only Colombia, 
Israel, and Pakistan. Remember the terror alert 
system? You know the Crayola crayon color-coded 
system any child could understand? Perhaps 
Dubya could explain to my eight year old son 
why the code has never dropped below yellow if 
we are safer from terrorism than we were a year 
ago. Little David keeps asking me that, but I 
can't give him a convincing explanation. 
Perhaps you could do it, Dubya, I mean you 
being the "education President" and all that? 
Why I even recall that no national crisis would 
stop you from finishing your lesson with 
elementary students. 

Actually, this losing is winning philosophy 
President Bush describes explains a lot to me. 
Not only does it explain the "War on Terror" 
and the "War on Drugs, " but it helps me 
understand how the massive budget deficit is 
good for our economy, how the massive trade 
deficit is good for the future of our nation, 
how the "Patriot Act" is good for my freedom, 
how refusal to sign the "Global Warming Treaty" 
is good for the environment, how developing new 
nuclear weapons helps stop nuclear 
proliferation, how government secrecy regarding 
energy, 911, Iraq (mis)intelligence, etc., is 
good for democracy, how....well, you get the 
point. In fact, according to this philosophy, 
George Bush must be the best president ever. 
But, Helen Thomas already said that.

David Wiggins is a West Point (United States 
Military Academy) distinguished graduate and an 
honors graduate of New York Medical College. He 
left the Army as a Conscientious Objector 
resigning his commission as an Army Captain on 
the Iraqi front lines during Operation Desert 
Storm. He is currently an Emergency Physician.
Copyright 2003 LewRockwell.com 
|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|*|

Subject: [sfraves] SAVE OUR MUSIC! SAVE OUR RIGHTS!

--=====================_431045==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

*****************************************************
ROAR!, The National Dance and Music Rights Alliance

SAVE OUR MUSIC! SAVE OUR RIGHTS!
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, NOON-MIDNIGHT
HTTP://WWW.ROARGROUP.ORG
*****************************************************

LET THE BEAT BE YOUR BALLOT!
DANCE TO THE FOLLOWING ARTISTS FOR FREE!

The Fabulous International DJ Superstar:
Junior Vasquez - Junior Vasquez Music - NYC (spinning at 6PM!)

DJ Craze - Six Time World Champion//The Allies//Cartel - Miami
D:Fuse - People:2 (2xCD) Out on System Recordings Now!
Jesse Saunders - King Street//Broken Records, Sony Music - Chicago, LA
Polywog - Just Say Agency// SisterSF - SF //From the Movie "Groove"
Reid Speed - Breakbeat Science//Direct Drive//NYC 2 Step - LA
The Zelch Brothers - Twin Prod.//Fused//412Groove.com - Pittsburgh
Apple Rochez - Odds and Ends//Lowdown//Natural Selection - DC
Proxxy - Instinctive Grooves//RaversOnly.com//M3 Productions - MD
Implicit - Electrolife - NC

With a Fabulous closing set by:
Scott Henry - Ultra Records//Buzzlife - DC

The US Government has declared a War on Music. We are the target of busts,
arrests, harassment and intimidation, all with the ultimate goal of destroying
our culture and silencing the music we love. The recently passed RAVE Act
threatens to scare club owners and promoters into shutting down events
nationwide for fear of imprisonment of up to 20 years and/or fines of 
$500,000.
Even harsher laws sit in Congress right now.

This summer, join ROAR! for a demonstration against the assault on music and a
festival for our civil liberties. We will display the force and unity of our
culture through performances by international artists and speakers from major
industry groups and politically influential organizations.

Invited Speakers:

Dennis Kucinich - 2004 Presidential Candidate, US Representative
Douglas Rushkoff - Author of Ecstasy Club, NYU
Graham Boyd - ACLU
Ira Glasser - DPA
Shawn Heller - SSDP
Sam "The Man" Burns - DJ Hut, DC House Legend
Amanda Huie - Buzzlife
Legba Carrefour - ROAR!
Keith Haas - 2AM Artist Management


EVENT LOCATION

Located @ the Upper Senate Park directly off Constitution Ave between
New Jersey NW and Delaware Ave NE, directly North of the US Capitol Building
Washington, DC

Parking is widely available both in the surrounding area and at Union
Station approximately 2 blocks to the North. There are facilities for the
offloading and parking of tour buses onsite. The Upper Senate Park is closest
to the Union Station Metrorail and train lines.

Tour Buses are being arranged from numerous cities. Please email
info@roargroup.org for any bus or general inquiries

----
ROAR! Would like to thank Instinctive Grooves, 2AM Artist Management, DC Life
Media, Paranormal Productions, Just Say Agency, System Recordings, Contagious
Music, One World Entertainment, Central Entertainment Group, and Buzzlife for
their assistance.



-- 
ROAR!
The National Dance and Music Rights Alliance
www.roargroup.org
202-546-2128



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_431045==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] FAULTLINE 5 - Sat 9/6 - Drum 'n Bass

FAULTLINE 5 
Saturday September 6 2003 
Drum 'n Bass & Oldskool Hardcore 

PIETER K (Breakbeat Science / Metaformal 
Recordings / Palette - LA) 
This highly-respected and thoroughly innovative 
producer has carved out his own unique sound with 
releases on labels such as Breakbeat Science, 
Renegade, Phunckateck, Thermal, Vortex, Higher 
Education and his own Metaformal. His debut 
LP, "Everything All the Time" dropped earlier 
this year as BBS's first full-length release and 
was lauded by critics at XLR8R, Knowledge, Urb, 
Mixer and countless other publications. His 
music is known for its intricate drum 
programming, emotional depth and dancefloor 
appeal. Pieter's career has included extensive DJ 
gigs all over the globe and we are excited to 
welcome him back to the Bay.
 
EHL (Warm Communications - Texas) 
Heading up the Warm Communications label with 
releases from such top-notch artists as Seba, 
Equinox, ASC, P.B.K., Banaczech and Probe One, 
EHL is known for his upfront high-tech 
atmospheric selection. He hosts a weekly radio 
show on http://bassdrive.com every Wednesday from 
4-5:30pm central which showcases the new, harder, 
dancefloor atmospheric sound. Don't miss this Bay 
Area debut! 

ILLFORMANTS (Breakbeat Science / Subtitles) 
Recording together as Illformants, Controlled 
Substance and Angelzero have received much well-
due attention. In addition to their solo careers 
they've turned heads with a single on BBS and two 
on Teebee's Subtitles label, including the wildly 
successful "The Bizarre" which continues to smash 
the top10s and playlists of a wide range of world-
class DJs. Watch out for these local favorites 
ripping up a tag-team FinalScratch session. 

DJ M (Faultline / The Tenderloft / Freebeats
Collective) 

FIFE (Faultline / InnerspaceResearchGroup) 

teKtite (Urban Terrorists / Elevation) 

new visual statements in the gallery by
SCATHA 
KELLY PORTER (Otherworld) 
KARA (Faultline) 

moving image by
L7VJ (Connected Systems) 

flyer by
INFLU3NZ (tsumimag.com - contact
influ3nz@tsumimag.com) 

online flyer:
http://faultlinednb.com/events/faultline5/front600.jpg
http://faultlinednb.com/events/faultline5/back600.jpg


10pm to after hours 
$10 until 11pm, $12 after 
all-ages underground san francisco location 
infoline: 415.435.7933 updated with location on day of
event
contact: hello@faultlinednb.com
visit: http://faultlinednb.com for mailing list signup
and more!

explore:
http://www.breakbeatscience.com/
http://www.metaformal.com/
http://www.paletterecordings.com/
http://www.warmcommunications.com/
http://www.bassdrive.com/

I just wanna thank all you promoters that booked me.  You gave me the time of 
my life.  You gave me wealth in more ways than one.  And I am just this Asian 
hermit that's always had this dream of being the next techno star...you help 
give me a chance to expose my music in a live pa kind of way...

truly connected...I sometimes hated this list, but i was addicted...because in 
the end of it all, i always cared what was going on in our beloved bay...

Dominic Son aka Reflector
www.reflectnow.com

I'll throw out the obvious answers...

> What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?

The wheel, for enabling most future technology.

> What is our worst invention and why?

The land mine, for being easily obtainable, easily placeable, and
impossible to completely recover.

-----Original Message-----
From: bodhi [mailto:teknobuddha@juno.com] 
Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 3:58 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list



Doodling in class and came up with a philosophical question to throw at
you:

What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?

I think perhaps the greatest invention/discovery was that of rhythm and
beat and harmony and the later induction of musical instruments.  It has
the ability to evoke all emotions within' oneself, its what people
people make when there's no electricity and they need to cure boredom,
its what our parents sing to us as children to put us to sleep or to
explain a concept, its what gets us moving on the dance floor and all
pain disappears, but it can be just as dark as it is good.  It's been
used in communications from the perspective of history and a means to
pass it from generation to generation to the code of maneuvers on the
battle field.  

I'm a little fragmented right now so my gammars and meaning is probably
all hosed but yeah.  Music. 

What is our worst invention and why?

The ability to write and read.  It is what destroyed/created
civilizations since those in power control language without meaning to
because it is a way to segregate others who can't.  I expect many people
to disagree with me on this, but what is philosophy without two sides.
Yes, poetry is wonderful, lyrics are wonderful, tales of far away lands
are wonderful, but all this was done by many a uncivilized people person
to person, father to son, generation to generation and people were able
to remember more and recall more since if they lost it it would be gone
forever.  

-Rayn

I'll give my answer latter.

Enjoy the brain exercise!
Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list


1) Written language. In complete opposition to Rayn, here -- I was sitting
around pondering (and reinstalling deus ex -- lots of guns, best game
ever) and as it struck me, I came back to read other people's responses.
Let's fight about it, Rayn! :) Before the written word, information was
subjective and easily contaminated: the problem with word-of-mouth
transmission of ideas is that each person who passes it on embellishes,
or forgets, or twists the tale or what have you to his viewpoint. Aside
from high ritual and religious/mystical traditions (and, often, those too
changed -- albeit more slowly) information before the written word was not
reliable or constant. It's arguable if it is now, but it certainly is an
improvement from playing telephone with your tribe. Written language /is/
what allowed civilization to flourish. And despite all the shit it's
caused, civilization is beautiful. Even our demented, psychotic, and
sometimes down right evil american civilization is beautiful.

2) I can't think of an invention we'd be better off without. I'm dead
serious. Knowledge is not 'bad'. Invention is not bad. The uses we put
these things to are... regrettable, but they're part of our progress as a
species. Either we'll survive our own madness or we won't. If we do, each
thing we've created -- even the worst things, the guns, the nukes, the
nerve gas -- will be a lesson we've learned. If the human race moves on to
become something better, it will only be because we made so many mistakes
along the way.

Alternately:

Philosophy/Philosophy.

Peace, love, onions,

The Rational Hatter

From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: bodhi <teknobuddha@juno.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030825.155831.18216.89906@webmail19.nyc.untd.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list

--- bodhi <teknobuddha@juno.com> wrote:
> What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?

Somebody already said the Wheel, so..  I'd have to say Mathematics.  As
much as the ability to quantify our world has created problems for us
as a race (such as..  The incessant drive to quantify the world), it's
enabled everything from the development of higher logic to computers to
astronomy to cash registers.  We'd be playing in the muck without it.

> What is our worst invention and why?

Explosives.  They're useful for blowing tunnels through mountains and
such, but apart from that they've given us guns, bombs, the internal
combustion engine (gas is an explosive), and all manner of other things
we use to kill ourselves and eachother on a daily basis.  Also, the
explosives paradigm fueled the advent of nuclear science (at least, the
facet which deals with splitting them), which has allowed us the power
to blow ourselves up even more efficiently.  Score.

Cheers,
GeorgeC
djorigami.com

Agriculture = movement from a nomadic existence to a stable platform for 
civilization = beer, wine and weed.


>What is our worst invention and why?

Coercive, manipulative, institutionalized religions.  More minds ruined and 
blood spilt over this than anything else....

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list

This is really getting interesting.  So many flip flops on what people think
is the best and worst.. :) Each listed so far has had so many positive and
negative things associated with it throughout history.  Except for sewers
(unless they're backed up) and Danny.  I'll have to say I agree with Apollo
on organized religion being worst which is where I really got my disgust of
the written language.  I think I should reclarify where the invention of the
written language is worst.  Many of the ancient civilizations that didn't
use pictograms only had a small number of people who actually knew how to
read and write.  Or lived in a place where only the social elite or monarch
was allowed to be literate  Even through time up until the late 1800's most
people didn't know how to read and write.  This is how religion was able to
have such a strong foothold and control the masses.  Religious leaders could
say whatever it is they wanted to say was written in there and the people
would believe it with no questions.  And unlike today they had no way to
communicate to others what they heard other than the phone game whereas now
we have live broadcasts, organizations setup to point out falsehoods etc.
So I guess it may be getting better as more and more people are able to
understand what's being written and able to see opposing viewpoints as well.
But I guess it really depended on which society you were in.  I think I'm
going to back off here and say that pet rocks and carpet tacks are the worst
things ever invented.
----- Original Message -----
From: "Sean Griffith" <srg@pdx.edu>
To: "bodhi" <teknobuddha@juno.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 5:13 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list


>
> 1) Written language. In complete opposition to Rayn, here -- I was sitting
> around pondering (and reinstalling deus ex -- lots of guns, best game
> ever) and as it struck me, I came back to read other people's responses.
> Let's fight about it, Rayn! :) Before the written word, information was
> subjective and easily contaminated: the problem with word-of-mouth
> transmission of ideas is that each person who passes it on embellishes,
> or forgets, or twists the tale or what have you to his viewpoint. Aside
> from high ritual and religious/mystical traditions (and, often, those too
> changed -- albeit more slowly) information before the written word was not
> reliable or constant. It's arguable if it is now, but it certainly is an
> improvement from playing telephone with your tribe. Written language /is/
> what allowed civilization to flourish. And despite all the shit it's
> caused, civilization is beautiful. Even our demented, psychotic, and
> sometimes down right evil american civilization is beautiful.
>
> 2) I can't think of an invention we'd be better off without. I'm dead
> serious. Knowledge is not 'bad'. Invention is not bad. The uses we put
> these things to are... regrettable, but they're part of our progress as a
> species. Either we'll survive our own madness or we won't. If we do, each
> thing we've created -- even the worst things, the guns, the nukes, the
> nerve gas -- will be a lesson we've learned. If the human race moves on to
> become something better, it will only be because we made so many mistakes
> along the way.
>
> Alternately:
>
> Philosophy/Philosophy.
>
> Peace, love, onions,
>
> The Rational Hatter
>
> On Mon, 25 Aug 2003, bodhi wrote:
>
> >
> > Doodling in class and came up with a philosophical question to throw at
you:
> >
> > What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?
> >
> > What is our worst invention and why?
> >
> > I'll give my answer latter.
> >
> > Enjoy the brain exercise!
> > Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^
