> Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 5:13 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list
> 
> 
> >
> > 1) Written language. In complete opposition to Rayn, here -- I was sitting
> > around pondering (and reinstalling deus ex -- lots of guns, best game
> > ever) and as it struck me, I came back to read other people's responses.
> > Let's fight about it, Rayn! :) Before the written word, information was
> > subjective and easily contaminated: the problem with word-of-mouth
> > transmission of ideas is that each person who passes it on embellishes,
> > or forgets, or twists the tale or what have you to his viewpoint. Aside
> > from high ritual and religious/mystical traditions (and, often, those too
> > changed -- albeit more slowly) information before the written word was not
> > reliable or constant. It's arguable if it is now, but it certainly is an
> > improvement from playing telephone with your tribe. Written language /is/
> > what allowed civilization to flourish. And despite all the shit it's
> > caused, civilization is beautiful. Even our demented, psychotic, and
> > sometimes down right evil american civilization is beautiful.
> >
> > 2) I can't think of an invention we'd be better off without. I'm dead
> > serious. Knowledge is not 'bad'. Invention is not bad. The uses we put
> > these things to are... regrettable, but they're part of our progress as a
> > species. Either we'll survive our own madness or we won't. If we do, each
> > thing we've created -- even the worst things, the guns, the nukes, the
> > nerve gas -- will be a lesson we've learned. If the human race moves on to
> > become something better, it will only be because we made so many mistakes
> > along the way.
> >
> > Alternately:
> >
> > Philosophy/Philosophy.
> >
> > Peace, love, onions,
> >
> > The Rational Hatter
> >
> > On Mon, 25 Aug 2003, bodhi wrote:
> >
> > >
> > > Doodling in class and came up with a philosophical question to throw at
> you:
> > >
> > > What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?
> > >
> > > What is our worst invention and why?
> > >
> > > I'll give my answer latter.
> > >
> > > Enjoy the brain exercise!
> > > Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list

Best Invention:  The Internet.

I know it sounds stereotypically nerdy.  But I really can't imagine how I got
along before the 'net.  Take the existance of SFRaves itself, and the
friendships I've formed through this very list.  The likelyhood of this
happening through another medium is slight.  The 'net has all but replaced
casual phone calls.  Now, instead of chatting with one person at a time on the
phone, I can talk to half a dozen ppl or so simultaneously.  And it had all but
replace the post officefor me.  And its usefulness as a research tool... if
there's anything I don't know... any fact that I can't recall the soruce of...
I don't have to go to the library, much around with card catalogues, drudge
through dead-tree crud.  All I have to do is type "www.google.com", and whe
world is at my fingertips.

Knowledge is power, as they say.


Worst invention:  Money

Just this last week, I lost my best friend because of a dispute over money. 
And the stink of it was, that *I* wasn't (well... shouldn't have been) involved
in said dispute; except that one party was do damn set on "winning" that he
just had to draw in and affect third parties.  So now, my best friend is gone,
and his friendship with ANOTHER person ended, because of money.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list



> 
> What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?

The semiconductor.  First used in a transistor.  Lead to computer, the
Internet, and on a grand philosophical level, expands the power of the
human brain.... and connects human brains like we are doing right now
with email.

> What is our worst invention and why?

There are no bad inventions.  Only bad application of inventions..

So, a better question would be, "What is the worst application of an
invention"

-troy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Philosophical question for the list

I think I'll start with the worst invention...prejudice.  It is, in my
experience, a learned behavior.  Be it racial, weight, sexual preference,
whatever.  I'm not saying I'm perfect or without any bias, BUT I do
challenge myself when I feel it coming on.  I challenge those around me as
well.  Hating someone or something for the sake of hating is ignorance at
its best.  Then there's the argument that just makes me sick:

"I didnt always feel this way about <insert random hated person, sect,
gender, etc here>, but one day I met this <insert random hated person, sect,
gender, etc here> and they did BLANK to me.....

Cop out city!

Best invention...Lube. Definitely.  Vaseline is just nasty.  Honey is stcky.
Baby oil only works when you have rubber sheets and a water bed.  Astroglide
however is the best.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


chanson du jour means "song of the day" in french, by the way...glad you could make it today! i am having an exciting week...trying to maintain...i am so sedate as a general rule that no one would know how excited i am accept for if they've been spending some time around me and kind of recognize how i am or if i were to share..so anyway, i am just completely elated and happy amist the sore spots...okay, today's chanson du jour came out of my mouth while i was getting dressed...it is either paul mccartney or the beatles...probably a combination of the two...you will recognize it..."yesterday...all my troubles seemed so far away...now it looks as though they're here to stay..oh i believe..in yesterday...suddenly...i'm not half the man i used to be! there's a shadow hanging over me...oh yesterday...came suddenly...why she had to go...i don't know...she wouldn't say...i said...something wrong how i long for yesterday...ay...ay...ay...yesterday....love was such an easy game to play...now
 i need a place to hide away...oh i believe...in yesterday...mmmm..mmmm.mmmm...mmmm...mmmm...mmmmmm...:O"  okay now the chanson est finis, donc, je parle un peu de d'autre choses....meaning, the song is over, i am going to talk about other things...now i forgot what i wanted to say...:) love, love, love...dodododdo, love, love, love...dododododo...all you need is love! all you need is love! all you need is love, love....love is all you need! :) :)


--0-1441475948-1061936783=:92025--

Subject: [sfraves] Re:[sfraves]Philosophical question for the list




> What is our (human beings) greatest invention and why?

  Electronic music. Electronic is a evolution of the first sound that came from the big bang 15b years ago in the east is called the OHM. Music fads and genres come and go, but electronic music is forever. Think about it, how many sounds can electronic music create? In a million years from now, if we don't kill ourselves, what sounds will be created? What will electronic music be like then? Electronic music represents our human potential. Since electronic music is boundless, our potential is boundless.

What is our worst invention and why?
>
  Ego. What I mean as ego is a self perception based on a concept of a seperate self, and from that we act in fear and self defence, the root of war and violence. Self isn't an invention, the contents are.

Peace, Bodhi

Here's a tip for those of you heading to Burning Man that haven't left
yet:

Sandra Collins will be doing a late night, extended set on Wednesday
night at the Opulent Temple of Kaos stage at "10:00 and Creed". I've
been invited to follow her up and keep things going at Magic Glasses
starting at 5:00am which is across the playa at "3:30 / Esplanade".

For some other interesting places to check out and the rest of my
"confirmed" appearances, you can check a special online version of my
newsletter at: HYPERLINK
"http://www.djdragnfly.com/dflynews-special.htm"www.djdragnfly.com/dflyn
ews-special.htm.

There's another big time headliner that will be playing along with us at
Sol System on Saturday night, but I've been vowed to secrecy. Come find
me and I'll let you know who will be making his debut at Burning Man
this year.

To those who can't go, I'll be thinking of you and if you're one of the
lucky ones who will be out there, come on and find me and let me show
you some crazy sites!!!

see y'all in a week!!!!

~dina HYPERLINK "http://216.40.249.192/s/contrib/ed/madfire.gif":devil

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  DJ Pierre at Club 6 on Friday

--=====================_13325304==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I'm not associated with Club 6, but I thought this might be of interest to 
the house heads out there.

Club 6's Legends of House series continues with DJ Pierre, the "godfather" 
of acid house, this Friday.

Much respect to DJ Pierre.  His involvement with house music goes back to 
its earliest days when, as a member of Phuture, he recorded the seminal 
"Acid Trax."   He departed for a solo career as a DJ and recording artist 
in the late 80s and became famous for his "Wild Pitch" sound, which was 
based on a lot of tweaks and effects.  Putting his own spin on the acid 
house genre he helped develop, wild pitch soon became a much-copied mode of 
production.  He's had hits as Photon Inc. and Aly-Us, but he hit a mild 
slump in the mid 90s that was ended with "The Horn Song."  In the tradition 
of the best tracks, it was alarmingly simple yet soulful, with an 
irresistible hook driven by a simulated trumpet.  The song was so 
successful that Strictly Rhythm decided to maximize its potential by 
drafting Barbara Tucker to add vocals.  Now known as "Everybody Dance," it 
crossed over to the pop market and revitalized Pierre's career.  He runs 
his own DJP Records and is again in demand as a remixer.

Also spinning:  Vince Lawrence and Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of 
house music.  Jesse is popping up all over these days.

I haven't seen DJ Pierre in some time, and Vince Lawrence is another 
Chicago house heavy.  Club 6 is fun, so I'm not going to miss this one.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_13325304==.ALT--

>its earliest days when, as a member of Phuture, he recorded the seminal 
>"Acid Trax."   He departed for a solo career as a DJ and recording artist 
>in the late 80s and became famous for his "Wild Pitch" sound, which was 
>based on a lot of tweaks and effects.  Putting his own spin on the acid 
>house genre he helped develop, wild pitch soon became a much-copied mode of 
>production.  He's had hits as Photon Inc. and Aly-Us, but he hit a mild 
>slump in the mid 90s that was ended with "The Horn Song."  In the tradition 
>of the best tracks, it was alarmingly simple yet soulful, with an 
>irresistible hook driven by a simulated trumpet.  The song was so 
>successful that Strictly Rhythm decided to maximize its potential by 
>drafting Barbara Tucker to add vocals.  Now known as "Everybody Dance," it 
>crossed over to the pop market and revitalized Pierre's career.  He runs 
>his own DJP Records and is again in demand as a remixer.
>
>Also spinning:  Vince Lawrence and Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of 
>house music.  Jesse is popping up all over these days.
>
>I haven't seen DJ Pierre in some time, and Vince Lawrence is another 
>Chicago house heavy.  Club 6 is fun, so I'm not going to miss this one.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>
>
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
>the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
>safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
>adventure or nothing."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
>a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
>we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
>recognize our shared humanity."
>-Pema Chodron
>
>"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
>-Dizzy Gillespie
>
>U

.. F8 & Psykofly [3:15:48]

Lots of crunchy hard tunes, sick dubs, old school teases, and even some
80s jams.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] No One Makes It to Burning Man



hee...

"I was organizing this boss techno-art project called 'Off The Grid,'" Kaegle wrote. "We were going to set up computer terminals in various parts of the playa and have people use them. Then we'd feed the binary data from those terminals into this fractals program that [Silver Lake, CA software designer] Ricky [Thomas-Slater] wrote. Those fractals would be sent, on the fly, to a group of exiled Buddhist monks I befriended online. The monks would transform the fractals into a temporal sand painting, the making of which we would webcast live to everyone on the playa."

Added Kaegle: "But I had to stop working on the monk thing to finish up this Pam's Country Crafts web site I'm working on. I really need the money."

Classic!

-troy

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Aug 2003 17:46:56.0868 (UTC) FILETIME=[35829A40:01C36CC3]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Secret of Happiness Explained

I've always known this to be true...now it's been confirmed.

Secret of Finding Happiness Explained
Money Can't Buy Happiness, but Health and Family Can

By  Jennifer Warner


Reviewed By Brunilda  Nazario, MD
on Monday, August 25, 2003
WebMD Medical News





Aug. 25, 2003 -- The key to finding happiness may be learning to shift 
personal priorities from the boardroom to the bedroom.


New research provides evidence to support the old adage, "You can't buy 
happiness." It suggests that people will find happiness by focusing more on 
family life and health issues and less on career and financial pursuits.


Researchers say people spend too much time worrying about achieving 
professional and monetary goals that may never bring them true happiness. 
But by devoting more time to personal health and family life, people will 
find lasting happiness.


Happiness Explained

Researcher Richard Easterlin, an economist at the University of California, 
argues that a new approach to finding happiness is needed that combines the 
two prevailing theories of happiness in psychology and economics.


According to the psychological view of happiness, each individual is born 
with their own setpoint for happiness that's determined by personality and 
genetics. Life events, such as marriage, loss of a job, and serious injury 
or disease, can temporarily raise or lower a person's level of happiness 
above or below this predetermined level, but they will eventually return to 
the original level.


In contrast, the economic "more is better" view of happiness argues that 
life circumstances and the growth of income have lasting effects on 
happiness.


But Easterlin argues that life events like marriage, divorce, and serious 
disability, have a lasting rather than temporary effect on happiness. And an 
increase in income doesn't necessarily bring lasting happiness because a 
person's expectations are also raised by through adaptation and social 
comparison as they achieve greater wealth.


A better theory of happiness, Easterlin says, should take into account the 
fact that happiness found through family life and personal health is 
affected much less by heightened expectations and social comparison than 
happiness sought through financial gains.


Make More Time for Health and Family

Easterlin says people make decisions assuming that more income, comfort, and 
positional goods will make them happier, but they fail to recognize that 
adaptation and social comparison will come into play and raise their 
aspirations to about the same extent as their actual gains, which leaves 
them feeling no happier than before.


"As a result, most individuals spend a disproportionate amount of their 
lives working to make money, and sacrifice family life and health, domains 
in which aspirations remain fairly constant as actual circumstances change, 
and where the attainment of one's goals has a more lasting impact on 
happiness," writes Easterlin.


"Hence, a reallocation of time in favor of family life and health would, on 
average, increase individual happiness," Easterlin concludes.





Ravin Riz
Guest Relaxation Specialist
Moksha Tribe
http://www.mokshatribe.net

"There is in this world no greater force than the force of a man determined 
to rise."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Secret of Happiness Explained

> According to the psychological view of happiness, each individual is born
> with their own setpoint for happiness that's determined by personality and
> genetics. Life events, such as marriage, loss of a job, and serious injury
> or disease, can temporarily raise or lower a person's level of happiness
> above or below this predetermined level, but they will eventually return
to
> the original level.

this is an interesting, but I belive flawed way of looking at happiness...
It would make more sence to look at happiness as a process instead of a
"thing" that can be aquired or lost.. so inorder to obtain "happiness" all
we need to do is repeat that process. now, it's true that for some this
process is triggered by acuireing wealth or having a stable home or good
health, but these are only triggers. It's posible to re-frame(taking a term
from NLP) any negitive situation into a positive and even change this so
called "pre-determined" level of happiness. So, what I'm saying is that
happiness is not an involuntary thing, it's something we do to our selves
when we are reminded to do so by triggers such as getting more money or
being in good helth, or just getting up in the morning and feeling that
first breath of fresh air from a new day...

Peace,
Mystic

-[http://www.lostways.com]-

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Secret of Happiness Explained

I think the first common mistake is to view happiness as a destination or a
goal. "If I acquire (XYZ) than I will be happy. If I lose, marry, gain or
change (XYZ) than I will be happy." Happiness can never be attained or
acquired especially if it involves outside influences. Happiness is a way,
not a destination.

From: <dank@countercultured.net>
To: "RaVin RiZ" <ravin_riz@hotmail.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; <moksha_tribe@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2003 12:25 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Secret of Happiness Explained


> its all about quality pussy!
>
> On Wed, 27 Aug 2003, RaVin RiZ wrote:
>
> > I've always known this to be true...now it's been confirmed.
> >
> > Secret of Finding Happiness Explained
> > Money Can't Buy Happiness, but Health and Family Can
> >
> > By  Jennifer Warner
> >
> >
> > Reviewed By Brunilda  Nazario, MD
> > on Monday, August 25, 2003
> > WebMD Medical News
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Aug. 25, 2003 -- The key to finding happiness may be learning to shift
> > personal priorities from the boardroom to the bedroom.
> >
> >
> > New research provides evidence to support the old adage, "You can't buy
> > happiness." It suggests that people will find happiness by focusing more
on
> > family life and health issues and less on career and financial pursuits.
> >
> >
> > Researchers say people spend too much time worrying about achieving
> > professional and monetary goals that may never bring them true
happiness.
> > But by devoting more time to personal health and family life, people
will
> > find lasting happiness.
> >
> >
> > Happiness Explained
> >
> > Researcher Richard Easterlin, an economist at the University of
California,
> > argues that a new approach to finding happiness is needed that combines
the
> > two prevailing theories of happiness in psychology and economics.
> >
> >
> > According to the psychological view of happiness, each individual is
born
> > with their own setpoint for happiness that's determined by personality
and
> > genetics. Life events, such as marriage, loss of a job, and serious
injury
> > or disease, can temporarily raise or lower a person's level of happiness
> > above or below this predetermined level, but they will eventually return
to
> > the original level.
> >
> >
> > In contrast, the economic "more is better" view of happiness argues that
> > life circumstances and the growth of income have lasting effects on
> > happiness.
> >
> >
> > But Easterlin argues that life events like marriage, divorce, and
serious
> > disability, have a lasting rather than temporary effect on happiness.
And an
> > increase in income doesn't necessarily bring lasting happiness because a
> > person's expectations are also raised by through adaptation and social
> > comparison as they achieve greater wealth.
> >
> >
> > A better theory of happiness, Easterlin says, should take into account
the
> > fact that happiness found through family life and personal health is
> > affected much less by heightened expectations and social comparison than
> > happiness sought through financial gains.
> >
> >
> > Make More Time for Health and Family
> >
> > Easterlin says people make decisions assuming that more income, comfort,
and
> > positional goods will make them happier, but they fail to recognize that
> > adaptation and social comparison will come into play and raise their
> > aspirations to about the same extent as their actual gains, which leaves
> > them feeling no happier than before.
> >
> >
> > "As a result, most individuals spend a disproportionate amount of their
> > lives working to make money, and sacrifice family life and health,
domains
> > in which aspirations remain fairly constant as actual circumstances
change,
> > and where the attainment of one's goals has a more lasting impact on
> > happiness," writes Easterlin.
> >
> >
> > "Hence, a reallocation of time in favor of family life and health would,
on
> > average, increase individual happiness," Easterlin concludes.
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Ravin Riz
> > Guest Relaxation Specialist
> > Moksha Tribe
> > http://www.mokshatribe.net
> >
> > "There is in this world no greater force than the force of a man
determined
> > to rise."
> >
> > _________________________________________________________________
> > Enter for your chance to IM with Bon Jovi, Seal, Bow Wow, or Mary J
Blige
> > using MSN Messenger http://entertainment.msn.com/imastar

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

there is absolutely no way you heard 2 bad mice nor
any other moving shadow artist on the radio in
1993..unless it was on steve masters live105 modern
mix.  he actually broke a bunch of good techno/
breakbeat jams.  i think the first time i heard da
juice 'hear the angels' was on his late night mix show
in 1991/2.  i believe 'bombscare' was released in
1992.  so i'd say 95-96 or so for 94.9 and the likes,
when radio DJ wankers did bootleg remixes of it.  but
not 93.    commercial radio had no idea of this stuff
back then..

chris

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV34oYyLkOYrx0001ddcb@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Aug 2003 20:05:26.0036 (UTC) FILETIME=[8E290540:01C36CD6]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

Look back to the early 90's and the birth of FreshJive clothing. That was
*rave* clothing 100% back then. It was *ug* clothing that was also popular
to wear *above ground*  At that time Live 105 didn't suck nuts like now and
they used to play  music from the rave scene which at that point was still
pretty ug and not widely known about here. Altern-8, Prodigy, Messiah, Utah
Saints, LA Style, 2 Bad Mice, Jay-Dee, and so on were all radio play. Are
you telling me that because it's on the radio it's no longer ug? Then what
is ug? Is this like that *I'm more punk than you* thinking? There ain't shit
these days that's really *ug* anymore IMO. The whole *ug* term is just a way
to set yourself apart from others and be more elite than the other guy.
There is and will always be leakage from the less-commercial side of things
into the commercial side. =)

:: r ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

Even though Steve Masters was a total drunk he did play awesome music. He
provided a lot of the soundtrack to my high school years (90-94). I remember
when he would do the ads for the Edge in Palo Alto. You'd hear The Shamen,
Eon, and other non-commercial radio play tracks being played. But the
Master's mixes... oh so cool. Remember when they did Transmitter
Adjustments? Used to hear all sorts of stuff you would normally never get to
hear! Then Live105 got bought by CBS, had an enema, and became a corporate
suckoff of a station. But 88 - 94 was good times. Remember when KMEL was a
top 40 station?? LOL.

:: r y a n ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Chris Jackson" <resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>
To: "Cheese" <itswidow@hotmail.com>; "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>;
<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2003 12:58 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK


there is absolutely no way you heard 2 bad mice nor
any other moving shadow artist on the radio in
1993..unless it was on steve masters live105 modern
mix.  he actually broke a bunch of good techno/
breakbeat jams.  i think the first time i heard da
juice 'hear the angels' was on his late night mix show
in 1991/2.  i believe 'bombscare' was released in
1992.  so i'd say 95-96 or so for 94.9 and the likes,
when radio DJ wankers did bootleg remixes of it.  but
not 93.    commercial radio had no idea of this stuff
back then..

chris

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

So one day you get a show//set on a radio station and you play music that
you would play at your own parties. You just cut your own ug nuts off in the
process by doing that? Hmmm... somehow I don't think that's right. If the
music that you hold dear as *ug* gets plaid in constant rotation then yeah -
no way in hell is that anything but commercial-pop. But once or twice, late
at night, most likely a weekend in know way makes things less *ug* or more
commercial.

References: <20030827200524.94489.qmail@web20209.mail.yahoo.com> <LAW9-OE48oV1qdiixjn00000331@hotmail.com> <20030827201516.3f4d1154154ffffff9a@hotmail.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Aug 2003 13:18:34 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <Law9-OE651MnactvMV500021957@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Aug 2003 20:23:53.0343 (UTC) FILETIME=[222AA8F0:01C36CD9]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

how can something be underground if it is in the spotlight? how can
something remain 'word of mouth' if it is being presented over the radio?
that is not 'underground', its 'mainstream' or 'abvove-ground'....

yes Ryan, that is correct... if i were to get a radio show and start playing
music that i consider to be underground, i would no longer consider those
tracks to be underground for the simple fact that they have been exposed to
the mainstream (i.e. none underground)... unless the show as a whole was
considered underground.... if it was a mainstream radio station then i would
no longer think the tracks to be underground....

what is more important, bringing your music to the masses (and still calling
it underground) or actually KEEPING IT UNDERGROUND? if people want to bring
the music to the masses then they have to realize that they will be losing
the "underground" label since it will no longer be "underground"....i am not
saying that either of the two is more correct; but you cant have both.... if
it is being played on a mainstream radio station, then it aint
underground... its that simple... it may have started out as being
underground, but is no longer underground....

See that's horrible. What that basically says to me is that you want to keep
this musci all to yourself and an exclusive circle of your liking. By having
one track touch a radio station, played once, it's not tainted and might as
well be a leper. Are you really this posessive over music and who should
hear it? If so that's kinda jacked. As far as I've ever been able to tell
you have been in this scene for the music first and foremost. It's the music
that keeps you around. Strangle the channels in which people hear the music
you love so much to only a *ug* environment and you gut out a lot of fresh
blood and the propogation of *new*  You dj because you want to share the
music you love with others...

the scene isn't comprised of punkrock attitude and those that front that
attitude miss out on so much...

:: r ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Cheese" <itswidow@hotmail.com>
To: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>; "Chris Jackson"
<resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>; "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>;
<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2003 1:18 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK


how can something be underground if it is in the spotlight? how can
something remain 'word of mouth' if it is being presented over the radio?
that is not 'underground', its 'mainstream' or 'abvove-ground'....

yes Ryan, that is correct... if i were to get a radio show and start playing
music that i consider to be underground, i would no longer consider those
tracks to be underground for the simple fact that they have been exposed to
the mainstream (i.e. none underground)... unless the show as a whole was
considered underground.... if it was a mainstream radio station then i would
no longer think the tracks to be underground....

what is more important, bringing your music to the masses (and still calling
it underground) or actually KEEPING IT UNDERGROUND? if people want to bring
the music to the masses then they have to realize that they will be losing
the "underground" label since it will no longer be "underground"....i am not
saying that either of the two is more correct; but you cant have both.... if
it is being played on a mainstream radio station, then it aint
underground... its that simple... it may have started out as being
underground, but is no longer underground....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

I always thought the "punk rock attitude" was to not sell out and stay
underground? And I don't think Tim was saying he wants all his music to stay
underground, I think he was simply saying that once something is playing for
the general masses it's no longer underground.


Nick
-http://www.hardcoreforthepeople.com

happy."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

thank you Nick....

that is precisely correct.... i do not want to keep all the 'ug' music
hoarded all to myself... actually, i am quite the contrary... i want to get
the music out so that more and more people can hear it and enjoy it as i
do.... but by doing that you can no longer call it 'underground'! for once
it has become 'above ground' it can no longer be called 'underground'....

doesn't this make sense Ryan? its not some super genious way of looking at
life; its more of a black/white way... its one or the other, and cannot be
both!

i really dont see how anyone cannot grasp that concept....

for

Subject: RE: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

But by that definition then no electronic music unheard or not would be
underground since raves and associated parties were broken into the
media around the mid-90's if not sooner thus destroying the udnerground
that we still believe is there.  We may still be able to pull off great
all night parties, not call them raves anymore, change the names of
genre's around but its not going to change the fact that unlike in the
early or even mid-90's if you asked someone if they heard of electronic
music or techno they'd just stare at you thinking you were talking about
disco or 80's music.

Its all perception.  To me underground means unheard by the masses and
the majority of people don't listen Subsonic or the other late night
shows on mainstream radio which are local to this area (and each area
that has a show like this).  Sure, something in rotation throughout the
day like Fisherspooner or Oakey or Prodigy would be mainstream or at
least above-ground, but everyone has to have a launchpad to the
underground and it's not always going to be word of mouth.  Techno
didn't just happen, it was pulled from ideas and samples from
above-ground music and media from every generation before it in an
evolutionary process.  My brother introduced me to the music which I
fell in love with but if it wasn't for local all-night alternative radio
with show's playing music from the "underground" I wouldn't have been
able to find out who to contact about finding raves in my own city since
he was from Denver and there wasn't quite a UTRaves yet (or an updated
one until I took over then gave up on as well,) nor did I know to look
for record shops and the clothing stores I went to had no fliers and
none of my friends knew what the hell I was talking about.

Image is nothing, obey the music you like regardless of where you hear
it.

-----Original Message-----
From: Cheese [mailto:itswidow@hotmail.com]=20
Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2003 1:19 PM
To: innocentchild; Chris Jackson; Brandon S.; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK


how can something be underground if it is in the spotlight? how can
something remain 'word of mouth' if it is being presented over the
radio? that is not 'underground', its 'mainstream' or
'abvove-ground'....

yes Ryan, that is correct... if i were to get a radio show and start
playing music that i consider to be underground, i would no longer
consider those tracks to be underground for the simple fact that they
have been exposed to the mainstream (i.e. none underground)... unless
the show as a whole was considered underground.... if it was a
mainstream radio station then i would no longer think the tracks to be
underground....

what is more important, bringing your music to the masses (and still
calling it underground) or actually KEEPING IT UNDERGROUND? if people
want to bring the music to the masses then they have to realize that
they will be losing the "underground" label since it will no longer be
"underground"....i am not saying that either of the two is more correct;
but you cant have both.... if it is being played on a mainstream radio
station, then it aint underground... its that simple... it may have
started out as being underground, but is no longer underground....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

The world isn't black and white. It's mostly grey area. The real question
comes down to a matter of opinion. What makes something UG and at what point
does it stop being UG? To you, in terms of UG music, as soon as that music
is played on open airwaves where the masses can hear it the music becomes no
longer UG. Suffice to say whether the station is commercial or not you're
playing to the masses. Really it seems more like if your UG music gets
played on a commercial station vs college radio or public access radio
that's a deciding factor in the demise of UG status. Take into mind
perspective. What's totally commercial to you is probably UG to some kid in
the mid west or else where. A side note to the commercial vs non-commercial
media mention earlier. The music is going out on all the same radiowaves
that are accessible to the masses. So really this is an anti-commercial
media argument you're making and not so much a pro-UG argument.

That said -
You have your opinion which says - *If it touches commercially owned
mass-media it's no longer UG even if it's played once*

I say that's BS. Just because some dj decided he liked a track that's UG and
played it once on the radio with all liklihood to be forgotton makes it no
longer UG? No way.

The next kid that's never heard any of the music you and I listen to might
hear that song and say - *WOW! What is this?? I've never heard this??* and
to him it's a taste of the underground and for that person that music *is*
UG to them.

It's all just opinion and yours is a lot more programmer like in it's
absolute nature. On or off. Yes or no. There is no maybe eh? =)

:: r y a n ::

thank you Nick....

that is precisely correct.... i do not want to keep all the 'ug' music
hoarded all to myself... actually, i am quite the contrary... i want to get
the music out so that more and more people can hear it and enjoy it as i
do.... but by doing that you can no longer call it 'underground'! for once
it has become 'above ground' it can no longer be called 'underground'....

doesn't this make sense Ryan? its not some super genious way of looking at
life; its more of a black/white way... its one or the other, and cannot be
both!

i really dont see how anyone cannot grasp that concept....

fund their less mainstream work.

bleed into the other.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

Not really feeling like arguing, however, I would like to point out:

 who the f**k is this "Mr. Underground" and why does he get to decide, 
which is which?
 is it Mr. and not Ms. ?

...Folks, I would have to say 'underground' is in the eyes of the beholder. 
And not to be ironic, what I just said isn't the end all standard either. 
What one may think is underground, may not be to the next guy (due to 
exposure to different experiences in life, level of participation in a 
chosen lifestyle, etc.).  And for that who cares? If I were to say "Gee, I 
am going to the best 'ug' party and you said 'Well, now Jack, that isn't ug' 
" - I would probably tell you to ... well, we'll just stop there.

To be honest, I think if you just stay true to yourself, that's all the 
underground you need to be. Might I suggest that being 'ug' is a way of 
thought and not of speech? Who cares if someone thinks I am not 'ug' - 
that's shallow and it surely doesn't dictate which events I go to, or what 
music I spin, or what clothers I buy.

If a track was so 'ug' that no one got to enjoy it, what good is that?

Considering this list is to be a haven for people who like to discuss EDM 
and related events, *sometimes* political happenings, Life Changes, etc. I 
feel that everyone is spending a little too much time on labeling what is 
and what it not.

Is Sfraves 'ug'?
Am I?
Are you?


--
DJ Jack Triumph
Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught

all i was trying to say was....

how could 2 BAD MICE be considered "ug" if a 5th grader in 1993 heard the
track Bomb Scare played (or should i say PLAYED THE FUCK OUT!) from a

listening to HOT97.7 listening to Bomb Scare by 2 Bad Mice.... dont get me
wrong, that track is sick! i love that track! but the fact that i heard it
from a mainstream radio station NUMEROUS times when i was only 12 should
show for something! i really dont see how that could be considered "ug"....

Subject: [sfraves] *DIGGA BEAT 2* AUG 30TH /ALL AGES! /PRESALES NOW IN STORES!

Hardcore for the People and Hardscience are proud to invite you to our 1
year aniv party. One year ago we started this crew with the intention of
helping a few of our friends get some more bookings. Well you all know what
it has turned into! So come out and help us kick of year number two for $8
bucks. We will have plenty of more surprises in store for this event so stay
tuned. Thanks for helping make this past year just absolutely amazing!!

dj's for the evening:

Cloudskipper (Liquidvinyldjs/Raw Elements)
Since his return to the bay area Cloudskipper has been delighting crowds
every weekend with his hardbeats and clean mixing. Expect nothing but the
newest most upfront hardcore.

Tronic (Resistance Recordings, liquidvinyldjs)
The bay areas very own US Hardhouse master mind will be dropping some of the
hardest hitting shit your ears have heard. Get ready to rock when Tronic
hits the decks!

Michael Liu (Illumination Records)
The psy-trance master is back once again to show the bay why he is Ca #1
psy-trance dj. Michael will be in full effect with some of the best psy you
will ever here. Expect nothing more than a heard pounding, earth shaking
mind blowing set.

MollyMush (Hardcore For The People)
Our very own Molly has been moving dance floors every weekend and earning
quite a name for her self. Her unique blend of hardcore flavor will have the
crowd pumped and dancing from begening to end of her set.

Leon Cook Vs Peter Go-Zania (HardScience/HCFTP)
The bald one and dumbo are going to have you rocking hard with a new style
hardcore set. So get ready for the pit when these fools step up to the deck.
This shit is gona get hard real quick!!

The Doctor vs Yagi (BayRaves, DeciBlast / HCFTP)
The Doctor has been building quite a name for himself over the past year and
is ready to get this crowd moving. Expect nothing more than the best jungle
has to offer when yagi and the doctor step up to the plate and crush the one
out of the park.

Paul Riley vs DvS Clevvy (core:NRG,DvS, HCFTP/ DvS Minds)
The two dvs ones are coming out ready to rock you. Get ready to dance when
these two drop one of the most energetic sets of the night.

Safe and Secure Bay Area Location with a ZERO DRUG TOLERANCE!
ALL AGES!
$8 PRESALES / $10 @ the DOOR
INFO: 408 380-3043
www.hardcoreforthepeople.com

Nick
-http://www.hardcoreforthepeople.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

who cares if it's 'underground' 99.9% of the people I have ever run into
only argue that something is or isn't underground based on popularity, are
social climbers, who don't really care about the music. I listened to a lot
of stuff on the radio as a child, that got me caring about music. is it bad
that it was on the radio? no. it was a very good thing, it got me interested
in the music. I'm sure the people making the music aren't fond of starving,
and don't mind getting a little airplay/fame to make enough cash to
eat/live.

do you think you'd be listening to the stuff you listen to now if you hadn't
heard what you heard on the radio in 1993?


Peace,
Beckka

> doesn't classify as

> On Wed, 27 Aug 2003, Damon Baxter wrote:
> 
> > Who told you that you were quality?????
> > j/k heh heh heh
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: <dank@countercultured.net>
> > To: "RaVin RiZ" <ravin_riz@hotmail.com>
> > Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>;
> <moksha_tribe@yahoogroups.com>
> > Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2003 12:25 PM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Secret of Happiness
> Explained
> >
> >
> > > its all about quality pussy!
> > >
> > > On Wed, 27 Aug 2003, RaVin RiZ wrote:
> > >
> > > > I've always known this to be true...now it's
> been confirmed.
> > > >
> > > > Secret of Finding Happiness Explained
> > > > Money Can't Buy Happiness, but Health and
> Family Can
> > > >
> > > > By  Jennifer Warner
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Reviewed By Brunilda  Nazario, MD
> > > > on Monday, August 25, 2003
> > > > WebMD Medical News
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Aug. 25, 2003 -- The key to finding happiness
> may be learning to shift
> > > > personal priorities from the boardroom to the
> bedroom.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > New research provides evidence to support the
> old adage, "You can't buy
> > > > happiness." It suggests that people will find
> happiness by focusing more
> > on
> > > > family life and health issues and less on
> career and financial pursuits.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Researchers say people spend too much time
> worrying about achieving
> > > > professional and monetary goals that may never
> bring them true
> > happiness.
> > > > But by devoting more time to personal health
> and family life, people
> > will
> > > > find lasting happiness.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Happiness Explained
> > > >
> > > > Researcher Richard Easterlin, an economist at
> the University of
> > California,
> > > > argues that a new approach to finding
> happiness is needed that combines
> > the
> > > > two prevailing theories of happiness in
> psychology and economics.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > According to the psychological view of
> happiness, each individual is
> > born
> > > > with their own setpoint for happiness that's
> determined by personality
> > and
> > > > genetics. Life events, such as marriage, loss
> of a job, and serious
> > injury
> > > > or disease, can temporarily raise or lower a
> person's level of happiness
> > > > above or below this predetermined level, but
> they will eventually return
> > to
> > > > the original level.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > In contrast, the economic "more is better"
> view of happiness argues that
> > > > life circumstances and the growth of income
> have lasting effects on
> > > > happiness.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > But Easterlin argues that life events like
> marriage, divorce, and
> > serious
> > > > disability, have a lasting rather than
> temporary effect on happiness.
> > And an
> > > > increase in income doesn't necessarily bring
> lasting happiness because a
> > > > person's expectations are also raised by
> through adaptation and social
> > > > comparison as they achieve greater wealth.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > A better theory of happiness, Easterlin says,
> should take into account
> > the
> > > > fact that happiness found through family life
> and personal health is
> > > > affected much less by heightened expectations
> and social comparison than
> > > > happiness sought through financial gains.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Make More Time for Health and Family
> > > >
> > > > Easterlin says people make decisions assuming
> that more income, comfort,
> > and
> > > > positional goods will make them happier, but
> they fail to recognize that
> > > > adaptation and social comparison will come
> into play and raise their
> > > > aspirations to about the same extent as their
> actual gains, which leaves
> > > > them feeling no happier than before.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > "As a result, most individuals spend a
> disproportionate amount of their
> > > > lives working to make money, and sacrifice
> family life and health,
> > domains
> > > > in which aspirations remain fairly constant as
> actual circumstances
> > change,
> > > > and where the attainment of one's goals has a
> more lasting impact on
> > > > happiness," writes Easterlin.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > "Hence, a reallocation of time in favor of
> family life and health would,
> > on
> > > > average, increase individual happiness,"
> Easterlin concludes.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Ravin Riz
> > > > Guest Relaxation Specialist
> > > > Moksha Tribe
> > > > http://www.mokshatribe.net
> > > >
> > > > "There is in this world no greater force than
> the force of a man
> > determined
> > > > to rise."
> > > >
> > > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

your missing the point Beckka..... what you hear on the radio is NOT
underground.... i am not saying that "non underground" music sucks, i am not
saying that "underground music" is superior to all others... i am not even
commenting on the quality of the music....

all i am saying is that the tracks you here on a mainstream radio station
cannot be considered "underground".... if that offends certain people
because "they are no longer listening to the cutting edge underground
shizat!" then i am sorry.... something being "ug" or not should have no
bearing on whether or not it is good.... it being good/bad is completely
different to being underground.... so dont think i am attacking the quality
of the music, because i am not... i am only stating that this so called
"underground" group/artist/producer/whateverthefuckyouwanttocallit is not as
underground as you may think....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

Actually Becky, Underground is a term coined by the music industry to music
that is not popular or has no appeal to the masses. The term underground was
commonly given to smaller record labels, like most of the punk in the 80's.
When I think of something that is underground I think of a small label (like
the one Chris Jackson runs) that doesn't have much promotion and well never
be something lots of people will ever enjoy.


Nick
-http://www.hardcoreforthepeople.com

happy."

> Actually Becky, Underground is a term coined by the music industry to
music
> that is not popular or has no appeal to the masses. The term underground
was
> commonly given to smaller record labels, like most of the punk in the
80's.
> When I think of something that is underground I think of a small label
(like
> the one Chris Jackson runs) that doesn't have much promotion and well
never
> be something lots of people will ever enjoy.
>

=3D Almost There =3D

                ... extremely unofficial Burning Man gathering


Couldn't make it to Burning Man this year?
Neither could we...=20
But that doesn't mean we can't have our own little slice of
Burning Man right here in the Bay Area!!

Join us for a trip into trance and psy
under the late night sky with:

DJ Eep                                            Cover: Free (Donations =
Excepted)
Jyant
Ohm
Sliver
DJ Jack Triumph
Penguin

INFO: (650)756-1322

Features:
    Tree House
    Large Fire (starts at 3AM)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] 2 BAD MICE - FRIDAY! / Aug. 29th / 5 STAR FUNK

how can I be wrong on my views on something? if you scroll down, you'll see
that I was asked what underground meant to me. That is what I think of when
I hear someone say some form of music is underground. I've met tons of
unsigned, not big, not on any radio, let alone mainstream radio, musicians,
but I refrain from calling them underground because that isn't what they are
trying to be. Infect they get rather annoyed when you call them that. Maybe
it's a thing from back east since I am have only been in cali for a month or
so, and the west coast for a few years prior to that.

Your Definition below may be what underground means to you, I wont tell you
that your views on a label are wrong, everyone is entitled to their own
views. so please have a little respect, and don't tell me my views are wrong
because they don't match with yours.


Peace,
Beckka

Subject: Re: [sfraves] One of charlottes best kept secrets.......... 


A couple rules we try to live by here:
* Do not send regional club mailings for out of state clubs to SFRaves.
* Do not crosspost (address to multiple lists in a single mailing).
* Please use a [bsp] in the subject when using the list for advertisement.
* Include pertinent info in the mailing itself (for example, a club
without an address is a pain in the ass)

andyw

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."

underground mean to you? How do you define it, and the music it
theoretically covers? keep in mind, this isn't limited to one genre of music
either since it's pretty much been agreed on that other forms of music have
their so called 'underground' music as well.

Part of language is accepted definitions for words.  We have compiled lists 
of meanings into books, called Dictionaries.  While you can choose to 
define a word in a different manner than what's commonly accepted, I 
wouldn't expect people to understand you.  You think I'm talking about 
underground?  How about infect?


sarilion


At 06:53 PM 8/27/2003, Becky Sibio wrote:

>how can I be wrong on my views on something? if you scroll down, you'll see
>that I was asked what underground meant to me. That is what I think of when
>I hear someone say some form of music is underground. I've met tons of
>unsigned, not big, not on any radio, let alone mainstream radio, musicians,
>but I refrain from calling them underground because that isn't what they are
>trying to be. Infect they get rather annoyed when you call them that. Maybe
>it's a thing from back east since I am have only been in cali for a month or
>so, and the west coast for a few years prior to that.
>
>Your Definition below may be what underground means to you, I wont tell you
>that your views on a label are wrong, everyone is entitled to their own
>views. so please have a little respect, and don't tell me my views are wrong
>because they don't match with yours.
>
>

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


Main Entry: 2underground
Pronunciation: '&n-d&r-"
Function: noun
Date: 1594
1 : a subterranean space or channel
2 : an underground city railway system
3 a : a movement or group organized in strict secrecy among citizens
especially in an occupied country for maintaining communications, popular
solidarity, and concerted resistive action pending liberation b : a
clandestine conspiratorial organization set up for revolutionary or other
disruptive purposes especially against a civil order c : an unofficial,
unsanctioned, or illegal but informal movement or group; especially : a
usually avant-garde group or movement that functions outside the
establishment

Main Entry: 3un·der·ground
Pronunciation: '&n-d&r-"graund
Function: adjective
Date: 1610
1 : being, growing, operating, or situated below the surface of the ground
2 : conducted by secret means
3 a : existing outside the establishment <an underground literary
reputation> b : existing outside the purview of tax collectors or
statisticians <the underground economy>
4 a : produced or published outside the establishment especially by the
avant-garde <underground movies> <underground newspapers> b : of or relating
to the avant-garde underground <an underground moviemaker> <an underground
theater>


Nick
-http://www.hardcoreforthepeople.com

happy."

Just in case you don't know what I was getting at

Main Entry: 1avant-garde
Pronunciation: "ä-"vän(t)-'gärd, "a-, "[a']-; &-'vänt-"; "a-"vOn-',
"a-"von(t)-'
Function: noun
Etymology: French, vanguard
Date: 1910
: an intelligentsia that develops new or experimental concepts especially in
the arts

> > of meanings into books, called Dictionaries.  While you can choose to
> > define a word in a different manner than what's commonly accepted, I
> > wouldn't expect people to understand you.  You think I'm talking about
> > underground?  How about infect?
> >
> >
> > sarilion
> >
> >
> > At 06:53 PM 8/27/2003, Becky Sibio wrote:
> >
> > >how can I be wrong on my views on something? if you scroll down,
> > you'll see
> > >that I was asked what underground meant to me. That is what I
> > think of when
> > >I hear someone say some form of music is underground. I've met tons of
> > >unsigned, not big, not on any radio, let alone mainstream radio,
> > musicians,
> > >but I refrain from calling them underground because that isn't
> > what they are
> > >trying to be. Infect they get rather annoyed when you call them
> > that. Maybe
> > >it's a thing from back east since I am have only been in cali
> > for a month or
> > >so, and the west coast for a few years prior to that.
> > >
> > >Your Definition below may be what underground means to you, I
> > wont tell you
> > >that your views on a label are wrong, everyone is entitled to their own
> > >views. so please have a little respect, and don't tell me my
> > views are wrong
> > >because they don't match with yours.
> > >
> > >
> > >Peace,
> > >Beckka
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: Sarilion [mailto:sarilion@sarilion.org]

FUNK

> > > > wrong.

> > > > certainly not on
> > > > mainstream radio.  It is underground rap music.  I'm not

http://www.mail-archive.com/

does the moderator want to add SFR to this archive? directions are =
below....

-------

How can I archive a public list?=20
  1.. Subscribe archive@mail-archive.com to the mailing list.=20
  2.. Mail-Archive does not respond to "confirmation requests". List =
administrators should add the subscription such that a confirmation is =
not required.=20
The Mail Archive automatically detects when it receives mail from a new =
list. Thus, you are encouraged, although certainly not required, to send =
a test message to the newly archived list. If you are adding several =
lists to the archive, send a separate and distinct test message to each =
one. During normal operation, email is archived shortly after it is =
received. In many cases, the new list will show up within a few hours. =
Sometimes, if there are enormous amounts of mail flying about, it can =
take much longer (over a day!) for messages to appear on the site. The =
new list will become searchable within one week.=20

IMPORTANT: The Mail Archive will create a publicly readable archive.=20


  a.. The Mail Archive merely provides an archival forum for mailing =
lists.=20
  b.. The Mail Archive does not necessarily agree or endorse any =
particular viewpoint posted to a mailing list.=20
  c.. The Mail Archive exercises no editorial control unless required by =
applicable law.=20

------=_NextPart_000_0072_01C36D6F.925F6A70--

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Cheese" <itswidow@hotmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 28, 2003 2:20 PM
Subject: [sfraves] SFR archive


i forgot who the moderator was.... so i am sendign this to the list.....

**********************

http://www.mail-archive.com/

does the moderator want to add SFR to this archive? directions are below....

-------

How can I archive a public list?
  1.. Subscribe archive@mail-archive.com to the mailing list.
  2.. Mail-Archive does not respond to "confirmation requests". List
administrators should add the subscription such that a confirmation is not
required.
The Mail Archive automatically detects when it receives mail from a new
list. Thus, you are encouraged, although certainly not required, to send a
test message to the newly archived list. If you are adding several lists to
the archive, send a separate and distinct test message to each one. During
normal operation, email is archived shortly after it is received. In many
cases, the new list will show up within a few hours. Sometimes, if there are
enormous amounts of mail flying about, it can take much longer (over a day!)
for messages to appear on the site. The new list will become searchable
within one week.

IMPORTANT: The Mail Archive will create a publicly readable archive.


  a.. The Mail Archive merely provides an archival forum for mailing lists.
  b.. The Mail Archive does not necessarily agree or endorse any particular
viewpoint posted to a mailing list.
  c.. The Mail Archive exercises no editorial control unless required by
applicable law.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Updates on the Anti-Rave Legislation

--=====================_18388743==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

RAVE ACT II

In the fight to repeal the RAVE Act we have come up against another piece 
of anti-rave legislation. If made into law, this latest attack on our civil 
liberties would open more doors for the prosecution of innocent business 
owners unable to stop drugs coming into their venue. Thousands of our 
supporters have already faxed their representatives about what we are 
calling the RAVE Act II (officially known as the Ecstasy Awareness Act) and 
groups across the country, like EM:DEF and ROAR, are mobilizing voters 
against the bill.

If you haven't faxed your Representative about the Ecstasy Awareness Act, 
please do so at: http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=4336

We also need you to fax your Representative about the CLEAN-UP Act if you 
haven't already. http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=4337

For more on what you can do to stop threats to hip hop and electronic music 
see: http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=4338


SEPTEMBER 6TH PROTEST AGAINST THE RAVE ACT

Thousands will gather at the Capitol in Washington, DC on September 6th for 
a musical protest against the RAVE Act and the continuing assault on dance 
culture. The event, sponsored by ROAR!: The National Dance and Music Rights 
Alliance, will feature Junior Vasquez, D:Fuse, booths, prizes, and much, 
much more.

Dance for your rights. U.S. Capitol, Washington DC. 1pm onwards.  For more 
information on the protest including directions see:

http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=4339


Tour Buses are being arranged from numerous cities. Please email 
info@roargroup.org for all general inquiries.


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

spirituality is whatever creates meanning for you consciously, or 
subconsciously.
raves vs. spirituality- of course it is spiritual.  Are you learning things 
if you are under the influence or not, yes.  Wether you want to or not your 
body is ALWAYS computing, gathering information, processing and then 
creating into meaning.  Information is meaning. learning=growth, 
growth=expansion=spirituality=knowing or not=death is 
spirituality=everything is spirituality because EVERYTHING HAS MEANING.
Due to "free will of the soul" we can decide for ourselves what we want to 
use it for/do with it/do/or be. I can even say to myself "Hey I think I know 
spirituality."
I can take a step back or four steps forward, stop, look around, take a big, 
deep breath and say
"I am alive!!!!"
Blessings to all!
Danny

> > How can I archive a public list?
> >   1.. Subscribe archive@mail-archive.com to the mailing list.
> >   2.. Mail-Archive does not respond to "confirmation requests". List
> > administrators should add the subscription such that a confirmation is not
> > required.
> > The Mail Archive automatically detects when it receives mail from a new
> > list. Thus, you are encouraged, although certainly not required, to send a
> > test message to the newly archived list. If you are adding several lists
> to
> > the archive, send a separate and distinct test message to each one. During
> > normal operation, email is archived shortly after it is received. In many
> > cases, the new list will show up within a few hours. Sometimes, if there
> are
> > enormous amounts of mail flying about, it can take much longer (over a
> day!)
> > for messages to appear on the site. The new list will become searchable
> > within one week.
> >
> > IMPORTANT: The Mail Archive will create a publicly readable archive.
> >
> >
> >   a.. The Mail Archive merely provides an archival forum for mailing
> lists.
> >   b.. The Mail Archive does not necessarily agree or endorse any
> particular
> > viewpoint posted to a mailing list.
> >   c.. The Mail Archive exercises no editorial control unless required by
> > applicable law.

  WHAT IS SPIRITUALITY?

  Spirituality is learning to connect to what is real, not how we like things to be, like seeing life without "rose colored glasses".

  Spitituality is finding what is natural, not only in the world, but what is natural for you, i.e. being gay/straight, being an artist, writer, computer nerd, school teacher, a/b personality, etc.
  
  Spiritual practice is connecting to what is natural

  Sprituality is NOT religion. What is the difference?
Sprituality = freedom to be you (natural)
Religion = some authority telling you how to be you (dogma)

Spiritual people tend to be attracted to nature
Religious people tend to be attracred to a orginization or a dogma

Spiritual people tend to want to be in natural places
Religious people tend to want to go to church and get dogmaticly reinforced

Spiritual people see divinity in all people
Religious people see divinity only in those who believe in their dogma

  DOES SPIRITUALITY BELONG IN RAVES?

  Without spirituality, raves would be like color without color. Spirituality is the soul (life energy)of raves. Bodies show up at raves, spirituality adds life.

  Everyone and everything is spiritual, dogma is the vampire of the soul.

 Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^


 "My religion is kindness,"
   (The Dali Lama)

At 09:24 PM 8/28/2003 +0000, bodhi wrote:


>  ...What is your defintion of spirituality and does it have a place in 
> raves and why?

Spirituality --

A monk asked Isan, "What is the Tao?"
"Mindlessness is the Tao,"  Isan replied.
"I don't comprehend," the monk said.
"All you need do is to apprehend the one who does not comprehend."
"Who is the one who does not comprehend?" the monk said.
"None other than yourself," replied Isan.

Does it have a place in raves, or on the dancefloor?  Spirituality is the 
essence of the dance experience or, as Frankie Knuckles said:

"From my particular end of it, it's like church.  Because when you've got 
three thousand people in front of you, that's three thousand different 
personalities.  And when those three thousand personalities become one 
personality, it's the most amazing thing."

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_26827853==.ALT--

> > >
> > > -------
> > >
> > > How can I archive a public list?
> > >   1.. Subscribe archive@mail-archive.com to the mailing list.
> > >   2.. Mail-Archive does not respond to "confirmation requests". List
> > > administrators should add the subscription such that a confirmation is
not
> > > required.
> > > The Mail Archive automatically detects when it receives mail from a
new
> > > list. Thus, you are encouraged, although certainly not required, to
send a
> > > test message to the newly archived list. If you are adding several
lists
> > to
> > > the archive, send a separate and distinct test message to each one.
During
> > > normal operation, email is archived shortly after it is received. In
many
> > > cases, the new list will show up within a few hours. Sometimes, if
there
> > are
> > > enormous amounts of mail flying about, it can take much longer (over a
> > day!)
> > > for messages to appear on the site. The new list will become
searchable
> > > within one week.
> > >
> > > IMPORTANT: The Mail Archive will create a publicly readable archive.
> > >
> > >
> > >   a.. The Mail Archive merely provides an archival forum for mailing
> > lists.
> > >   b.. The Mail Archive does not necessarily agree or endorse any
> > particular
> > > viewpoint posted to a mailing list.
> > >   c.. The Mail Archive exercises no editorial control unless required
by
> > > applicable law.
> > >

From sfraves-return-105416-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Aug 29 03:00:18 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-105416-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 63914 invoked by uid 1103); 29 Aug 2003 03:00:17 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 63895 invoked from network); 29 Aug 2003 03:00:17 -0000
Message-ID: <20030829030013.34531.qmail@web41904.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Aug 2003 20:00:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: miss g <rhythmzslave@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030828.171825.22255.42907@webmail07.nyc.untd.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Another brain exerciser...

> Religious people see divinity only in those who
> believe in their dogma


er-i bed to differ.  first of all, i don't just 'see'
divinity, i feel it, that's how i know about it.  i
feel it in many different places, most intensely,
however, when i'm connecting to music, whether that be
inside church or outside of it..in  my room or at a
rave, trancing out in blissful delight.  when it comes
to 'seeing' divinity, in a smile from a friend, in a
selfless act of kindness from a stranger, or from an
amazing performance of music or art, i feel it, and
know it is there, whether or not i have any knowledge
of the other person's faith. 

i connect with divinity as much in a church as i do by
the ocean, in the forest, or at a good rave, many
religious people take their faith with them, if they
believe God created this world to some extent, it is
His home too, and therefore the ocean is as much His
home, if not more so, than a manmade church.  

please, if you are not religious, please do not try to
speak on our behalf, or tell others what we apparently
like or dislike are open to or are closed to.

most of my friends are not religious, but we connect
on amazing levels of spirituality and friendship (the
two are intertwined i believe) ..precisely because we
both connect to divinity through realizing the beauty
of certain places or entities (music) or people.we
share thoughts on learning about ourselves and the
world and our connections to the cosmos at large. 

there are also many 'religious' who respect and
respond to the wisdom poured forth from a variety of
sources, including ghandi, the dalai lama, and mother
theresa, and other spiritual leaders, and incorporate
their teachings into their lives...there is not
necessarily one 'dogma,' that even the most religious
people believe in.  

if these comments are due to your experience with
other 'religious' people, i am very sorry for you and
them, that neither of you had better, more fruitful,
more open experiences.

lastly,


"Spiritual people see divinity in all people"
let me explain one more thing: many Christians believe
that God formed man, "in His image," meaning in the
image of God.  therefore, every human being is a
reflection of the glory of God.  millions of people
believe in the divinity of every human being, EVERY
human being, and the dignity of that human being, from
the start of life to the end.  again, in EVERY human
being, regardless of background, regardless of faith,
because like God, man has an immortal entity attached,
that being the sol.  for some, this 'dogma,' as you
call it, reminds them that all men are created equal,
and all are equal under God's eyes.  

if you do not like the idea of human beings needing
this 'reminder' via dogma, i can understand that. we
shouldn't need a 'reminder,' we should just know,
feel, realize that we are all one, we are all together
in this life, but some people need a reminder.  if
this reminder does in fact bring them closer to other
humans, closer to themselves, and closer in their
connection to all of creation, i do not understand how
you could say that 'dogma' is a vampire.  spiritual
people are not the only people who see divinity in all
people.

i do not claim to know your spirituality because you
are not of my faith.  i do not lump 'nonreligious'
together and set them aside from me. i would
appreciate not getting lumped into a category of
'religious' and then having someone else place
definitions on said 'religious' because i believe in
some things of what you would call 'dogma.' as every
human being is different, so we all have different
spiritualities, different ways of realizing divinity
and coming closer to one another and ourselves, and as
such i would never presume to know someone else's
world view simply based on whether they followed
'dogma' or not. we are all one, we are all part of the
divinity that has been running through us since
creation.

please, let us try to understand each other (religious
and non-religoius), instead of claiming to know what
the other believes.  

peace,
lauren


--- bodhi <teknobuddha@juno.com> wrote:
> 
>   WHAT IS SPIRITUALITY?
> 
>   Spirituality is learning to connect to what is
> real, not how we like things to be, like seeing life
> without "rose colored glasses".
> 
>   Spitituality is finding what is natural, not only
> in the world, but what is natural for you, i.e.
> being gay/straight, being an artist, writer,
> computer nerd, school teacher, a/b personality, etc.
>   
>   Spiritual practice is connecting to what is
> natural
> 
>   Sprituality is NOT religion. What is the
> difference?
> Sprituality = freedom to be you (natural)
> Religion = some authority telling you how to be you
> (dogma)
> 
> Spiritual people tend to be attracted to nature
> Religious people tend to be attracred to a
> orginization or a dogma
> 
> Spiritual people tend to want to be in natural
> places
> Religious people tend to want to go to church and
> get dogmaticly reinforced
> 
> Spiritual people see divinity in all people

> 
>   DOES SPIRITUALITY BELONG IN RAVES?
> 
>   Without spirituality, raves would be like color
> without color. Spirituality is the soul (life
> energy)of raves. Bodies show up at raves,
> spirituality adds life.
> 
>   Everyone and everything is spiritual, dogma is the
> vampire of the soul.
> 
>  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^
> 
> 
>  "My religion is kindness,"
>    (The Dali Lama)
>

From: Terry Estioko <terry@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: terry@atari

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] More on Archives

Today's inquiry prompted me to pull out a random month of SFR archives
(3-96) to read, and wow, what a crazy trip through memory lane.

If anyone is having difficulty pulling out the archives, just ask me, or
anyone on this list. Essentially, they are sorted by month and year, and
gzipped into single files that most computers should have no problem
downloading and un-zipping. What you are left with is a huge text file
which requires a text editor, bbedit, notepad, etc. (dunnno I use bbedit)
to search through or just scroll. Of course you could also grep them as well.

It's really crazy: the general attitude (we can do ANYTHING), newness of
it all, and yeah...even talk of what undergound *is* is what what is
considered old-school and how things aren't what they used to be. The "in"
ASCII sigs were cool too.

Even stranger (for me at least), is as I scroll the posts I see people
whom are still part of the scene today, and people who've become valued
lifetime friends. Cool stuff.

I think around that time was when I met Philip X Diaz (Euphonic Genesis
;-), Danny Picard, Troy Sheets, JOnas, and a few other current listers
that are active today.

Thank goodness I used a screenname in my early, naive years. What a corny
dumb-ass terry was ;-)

Archives are available here: http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/

PLUR,

-terry

------------------------------------
terry estioko | terry@viberation.com
http://www.estioko.com
http://www.viberation.com

and the lighting is spriitual as well. for example take the lord of the rings 
two towers... when gandolf explains how we almost died while fighting the 
demon dragon thing is shows the whole process where he almost dies and transforms 
from gandolf the grey into gandolf the white... durring the process you see 
lots of flashing floresent psychodelic lighting... just like at a rave! 
in conclusion i think the lighting also induces a spiritual experience and we 
are too perhaps transforming our grey matter into white.

And also the BPM's induce spirtuality which has been known for a long time by 
achient tribes around the world.


So now we have #1 Dancing #2 Atmospheric and electronic music # 3 Pyschodelic 
and cosmic-like lighting # 4 Tribal-like BPM's this combined wiht the 
excitement of a mass social gathering and an influence of shamanistic drug use... it 
would be insane to say that spiriutality doesn't have a place at raves

and it's not like spirituality is a part of raves because spirtuality is a 
part of eveyrthign like someone was saying... there's a big huge difference 
there's a peak and explosion of spirituality at raves where at spirituality is 
subtle in every day life.

--part1_5b.3d84f3d4.2c806c2c_boundary--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Another brain exerciser...

I wouldn't be so quick to put down organized religion as a whole. Lets not
forget that a ot of the philosophies you are talking about are Buddhist and
stem from an organized religion.. Dogma is a guide line, a kind of map of
your path. and it's true, some can just wonder aimlessly into the redwoods
naked and smiling and find "spirituality" but others enjoy following a map.
My belief, however, is that they both lead to the same place.

Spirituality to me is believing that there is something beyond
individuality, that things are invisibly connected somehow.

as far as raves are concerned, raves do model shamanistic ritual, and ritual
dancing festivals. Raves gather a lot of energy in one place, but the energy
usually just bounces around feeding of its self and never put to any good
use.

Peace,
Mystic

-[http://www.lostways.com]-

From: "bodhi" <teknobuddha@juno.com>
