Subject: Re: [sfraves] Another brain exerciser...


>
>   WHAT IS SPIRITUALITY?
>
>   Spirituality is learning to connect to what is real, not how we like
things to be, like seeing life without "rose colored glasses".
>
>   Spitituality is finding what is natural, not only in the world, but what
is natural for you, i.e. being gay/straight, being an artist, writer,
computer nerd, school teacher, a/b personality, etc.
>
>   Spiritual practice is connecting to what is natural
>
>   Sprituality is NOT religion. What is the difference?
> Sprituality = freedom to be you (natural)
> Religion = some authority telling you how to be you (dogma)
>
> Spiritual people tend to be attracted to nature
> Religious people tend to be attracred to a orginization or a dogma
>
> Spiritual people tend to want to be in natural places
> Religious people tend to want to go to church and get dogmaticly
reinforced
>
> Spiritual people see divinity in all people
> Religious people see divinity only in those who believe in their dogma
>
>   DOES SPIRITUALITY BELONG IN RAVES?
>
>   Without spirituality, raves would be like color without color.
Spirituality is the soul (life energy)of raves. Bodies show up at raves,
spirituality adds life.
>
>   Everyone and everything is spiritual, dogma is the vampire of the soul.
>
>  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^
>
>
>  "My religion is kindness,"
>    (The Dali Lama)

Subject: [sfraves] Last "DETROIT" this Sunday night @Skylark (BSP)

--0-1923354468-1062192187=:78729
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


Check it out - This Sunday will be the last edition of Detroit while we take a hiatus of unknown length. It has been a rich experience - a chance to contemplate and savor the sounds of a city and the soul of a place - which of course, is its culture and people. (Sniff sniff!) We'll be back, for sure, but for now, its time for a break!

SO- THIS SUNDAY - Please join DJs Baby Daddy, 12 Mile, Domingo Yu and Bartenders Peter Lakis and Scott Campbell as we mix up a whole lot of good vibes. 

AND, for the first time the Woodward Posse will be in full force! "Silent" partner Domingo Yu has DJ'ed around the D and the world and represents equally well as a hip hop and techno selecta. He's shared the stage with acts ranging from Eminem to DJ T-1000, Xzibit to Derrick May. 

Bringing the rock factor, DJ "12 Mile" aka Brian Stein will send the weak-hearted running and reward "those who know" with his mix of Detroit Rock City and Motown classics. 

Wrapping things up with a shiny bow is DJ Baby Daddy - you know 'em, ya love 'em, and you know he's gonna play "Sandwiches" so what else really needs to be said??! ;)

Detroit is free, and starts at 9 this Sunday night at the Skylark, 3089 16st., San Francisco. 

Thanks - The Woodward Posse

http://www.domingoyu.com/
http://www.rumpshaker.net/pirateradio.php
http://www.ghettoblasta.net/

Subject: [sfraves] :CODE WAS SOOOOOO DOPE!!!!! HELLO 2DAY!

OK... WOW... the night was soooo Dope!!!  I mean... ok... so I went 2 the City like right after work 'cause I did wanna check out that Sister Thing @ Wish on Folsum... I mean.. I realy went 'cause I wanted 2 C Seraphim 'cause I miss that girl sooo much!  She wasn't spinning, but I hung out w/ Queen Agness (sp) B 4 a bit!!  Oh yeah... while I was walkin' 2 Wish... I bumped in2 Audio El from Cybrid along the way there... LoL... He So Dope!  Then I went 2 visit Happy Kid Marty @ his work & we hung out 4 like a few minutes!!  It was Dope!!  His hair is like sooo short now!!  Hello 2Day!!  Then I went in Butter 4 a quick minute & said what up 2 Big J the bartender =)

So since things well it was like only 7:30, so I said fuck it... I went 2 DNA 2 watch them set up!!  I mean... might as well go all the way, right?!   I mean... set up was kinda Groovy 'cause I liked how they were setting up the stage w/ all them live acts!!  Wow!!!  Oh gosh... I Loved it when they did sound check.. so much Lovely Noise playing!!!  So I went & helped out Kara a lil' who was hangin' her art...It was Dope!  DJM & Leslie came by 2 help... 

OK... I really have 2 say that Dusty Brown is sooooooooo fuckin Awesome!!!  Oh mY gosh man... he opened & it was like all this Ambienty stuff w/ small lil jungle ummm chords, thrills, chimes whatever like running all throughout the ambiant stuff that was goin on... I Loved It!!  OK... then he busted out w. this Awesome Fuckin' Jungle & man... the live shit he was doin totally jus' ooh man... it was Orgasmic!  There was even a part where he went down tempo-ie for a while, but lifted it back & got in2 some hard Jungle that jus' fucked me up!!  I mean... it was all crazy ass basslines & all these dope sounds all crazy & wow!!  1 of my favorite songs he did live was this, OK.. I think it was his live set, when he busted out a rock song, but to a jungle beat w/ all these guitars playing!!!

But I guess towards the end of his live set... DJM, Kara, Leslie, & I went out 2 get dinner!  Yum!!  Thanks DJ M 4 getting me 4 dinner =)

Anywaze, we got back like probably an hour later or something like that & grrrrr... missed Amber spinning w/ that live drummer & I felt like sooo bad about that!  But we like totally walked in on like this Live PA duo don this like Hip Hop mixed w/ Lounge Music set!!  They were Cool!!  Oh yeah... & the place totally filled up while we were gone!!  Alooooota people showed up yaaaaay... it was a total family afair!!  It was Groovy!! unfortunately... I missed Jack Triumph as he was leaving =(  

BUt the upstairs up was open & it was Dope... The Sleeveles Records Chicas were doin this total tag set!!!  LOVED IT!!!  Hello 2day... all the tracks were Dope, the floor was bumpin the whole nightr up there in that hot small room!  Oh oh oh oh. I finally kicked it w/ Audio Angel Again yyyyyaaaaaaaaayyyy!!!  That was CooL... I Love That girl!!  We always have the best time 2gether!

while I"m still talkin' about the upstairs... UFO went on after the Femmes & Eva eerrr Ultra Violet, then UFO went on... WOW!!!  he spun Records while mixing in CDs while playing some live shit off his lil' imac book thingie!!  Hello2Day.... fuckin' Loved it man!!!

OK... back 2 down stairs----> There was another Live PA act... OK... if I remember correctly... they were doin; like these ummmm.... i wanna say like twisted breakbeat songs... it was wierd... then there was a DJ scratching while these dudes played their live music... it was a fun live set & there were moments I danced there!!

OK... then Shank went on & spun these totally awesome fuckin' oh gosh... the break beats he spun were so fucked up & evel & wicked that I Loved it soooooo much!!!  I danced as much as I could during his set!!  it was Dope!!!  I mean... the whole set it was like that!!! Thank U Skank ooops I mean Shank! =)

OK... Then Cybrind went on & yeah... they were in full Run DMC/ Flava Flav gear!!  Now there live set was fuckin' Aweome!!  I mean... I coulda sworn that they started out doin like live breakbeats that later turned in2 full on Electro!!  But man... their songs... so Awesome!!  There was this 1 song in patcular that I Loved during the middle of their set when it was this drum beat playin, then this weird like this stringy bouncey chord went on 4 like 64 measure, then this other synthy sound like layed over it 4 like another 64, then this solid blobby loop layered over that & then solid bassline went in there somewhere sometime & it produced this Awesome Melody that jus' WOW... as tired as I was... I totally got on the floor & danced!!  It waws fuckin Sik!!  Loved it!  Then all of sudden when I was like used to that oddly strange but totally beautiful meoldy... they totally went in2 this mondo change!!  LoL... I was Hella yelling!!  YAY!!!

The night was great itself!!  I finally hung out w/ Dann Carr again after well... I saw him briefly @ Jagan, but we kicked it hardcore in the jungle room during code!  Oh My Gosh.. Hello 2day... so yeah... Ryan got his Birthdas Groovy on Lush style & it was fun watching him well... make an ass of himself 1/2 the whole night while he waws swervin'!!  It was fun... but Fuckin' shit man... he hit me in the head hella hard 2 get my attention @ this 1 point & ow... that hurted!!  BUt yeah... 2 name every who was there!  In short I can say, Old Skool, Middle skool, & New skool sfr people were there, Friendster were all around, & the vibe was so sweet the whole night!!  Wow... I Loved it!!!

Thank U :code 4 2 years of Amazing music!!  Love U :code!


Take Care,

***Wed. 9/24/03 Selekta.com-Progressive Soul w/guest Paul Lancaster***


PAUL LANCASTER-uk. (Sabotage Systems, Climax Recordings, CP Recordings )

Born and raised in Newcastle Upon Tyne, England - 26yr old DJ and producer
Paul Lancaster was first introduced to the sounds of acid house and techno
by local pirate radio station Wear FM in the early 90s.

Inspired by the DJ mix tapes of Carl Cox that he heard at school, Paul
quickly embraced the local underground rave scene and began honing his own
mixing skills with the techno and breakbeat he discovered at Bass Generator
Records and the deep house grooves of Trax (now Flying Records) in
Newcastle.

Following a move to Leeds, Paul drew further influence from the diverse
mixture of funky vocal house and US garage at club nights such as Up Yer
Ronson, Back 2 Basics and Hard Times along with the techno and breakbeat of
the Orbit and Warehouse. After a short spell DJing for fashion shows and
promoting his own club nights in Leeds, Paul returned to Newcastle with a
new found confidence as a DJ and a burning desire to break through as a
producer in his own right.

Over the next few years Paul took his first tentative steps towards
production, remixing a number of house classics for his own DJ use and his
first full production in the form of debut single 'Bad Girl' that was
quickly signed to local house label Climax Recordings in Newcastle.

Following the international success of 'Bad Girl' and 'The Gringo Trail' for
Climax, 'Don't Stop Burning' was soon signed by Cass to Sabotage Systems for
release in March 2003 and is currently featured on the Sabotage compilation
album '8 - Live @ Centro360' mixed by Cass.

Paul continues to work as A&R manager, DJ and resident producer for Climax
Recordings in the UK with a number of his productions and remixes set for
release on various labels throughout the year. His latest single 'Night
Vision' has enjoyed big support already from the likes of Danny Howells,
Hernan Cattaneo, James Zabiela, Randall Jones and Mark Pappas of Tigerhook
Corporation plus a whole host of select DJs from across the world.

Paul is also the resident DJ and promoter of the Fragile club nights in
Newcastle and with an eclectic mix of musical styles, recent productions
have found strong support with some of the worlds best DJs whilst his own
reputation as an accomplished DJ mixing the very best in house, tribal,
tech-house and breaks continues to grow far and wide.

DJ support from John Digweed, Sander Kleinenberg, Danny Howells, Cass, James
Zabiela, Hernan Cattaneo and many more.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

bodhi <teknobuddha@juno.com> wrote:
WHAT IS SPIRITUALITY?

Spirituality is learning to connect to what is real, not how we like things to be, like seeing life without "rose colored glasses".

Spitituality is finding what is natural, not only in the world, but what is natural for you, i.e. being gay/straight, being an artist, writer, computer nerd, school teacher, a/b personality, etc.

Spiritual practice is connecting to what is natural

Sprituality is NOT religion. What is the difference?
Sprituality = freedom to be you (natural)
Religion = some authority telling you how to be you (dogma)

Spiritual people tend to be attracted to nature
Religious people tend to be attracred to a orginization or a dogma

Spiritual people tend to want to be in natural places
Religious people tend to want to go to church and get dogmaticly reinforced

Spiritual people see divinity in all people
Religious people see divinity only in those who believe in their dogma

DOES SPIRITUALITY BELONG IN RAVES?

Without spirituality, raves would be like color without color. Spirituality is the soul (life energy)of raves. Bodies show up at raves, spirituality adds life.

Everyone and everything is spiritual, dogma is the vampire of the soul.

Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net

Date: Sat, 30 Aug 2003 18:06:12 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_25680664==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6

--=====================_25680664==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I had been looking forward to Club 6's "House of Legends 4.0" event for 
weeks.  Hell, just about any event at Club 6 these days is a guaranteed 
good evening for me:  friendly staff;  free and non-judgmental space; 
underground vibe; and an eclectic, respectful dance crowd.  Further, they 
throw some fine house music parties.  Last night's "Legends 4.0" was one of 
those rare "in the zone" evenings for me.

We arrived during David Coleman and Sen-Sei's set.  Those two are 
consistently energizing performers and they got my groove going.

Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of house music followed.  I've had 
ambivalent feelings about Jesse since back in the day.  But next year marks 
the 20th anniversary of the release of the first house recording, his "On 
and On." That was the beginning of a life-long passion for many of us, so I 
give him his due.  It turns me off, though, when he begins his sets these 
days with his "...here is the originator of house music" promo, as if we 
all didn't know.  Such BSP.  And I didn't really expect that much from his 
set.  Jesse was never a great DJ or, for that matter, producer.

I thought the first half-hour or so of his performance was programmed and 
uninventive, but the crowd felt otherwise.  This was not the old school 
house head group I've danced with over the years.  As one of the few 
old-timers there said to me:  "I don't know any of these 
kids."  Excellent.  A genre dies without new lovers, and these people who 
had never heard most of this old school music  were jacking their bodies 
like house's first lovers two decades ago.

My main reason for coming to this party, however,  was to hear DJ Pierre.

DJ Pierre -- Nathaniel Jones is his given name -- is right up there with 
Larry Levan, Marshall Jefferson, Adonis and the like:  genuinely awesome 
innovators who laid the foundation for house and electronic dance music.  I 
worship the man.  While tripping on acid back in eighties Chicago he and 
some friends invented acid house while tweaking with a Roland TB303.  Acid 
house was the genre that set fire to the rave movement in the UK and then 
the states in the late eighties.

If I was given a choice of the DJs I would be willing to dance to for an 
eternity on that big dance floor in the sky, it would be Larry Levan and DJ 
Pierre.  Larry, though, is forever frozen in time in my soul.  Pierre has 
evolved over time, and has been a symbol for many in the house community 
for the radical, progressive soul of house music.

When Pierre moved to NYC he took acid house even further, creating a sound 
that wedded funky brass and vocals to Chicago acid:  wild-pitch.

In addition to being a prolific and paradigm-busting producer, DJ Pierre is 
also a very competent DJ.  His set last night was truly amazing.  I was so 
overcome with respect and emotion when I went up behind the decks to greet 
him, that I took his hand and kissed it.  A bit over the top, I know.  But 
it was genuine and spontaneous.  And there I stayed for most of his set, 
right behind the decks,  dancing joyfully, in perfect harmony with the 
universe, totally happy.  One cherishes times like these.  Doesn't get much 
better....

Vince Lawrence didn't show, for whatever reason, so Jesse took over the 
decks after Pierre's extended set.  Jesse was wonderful.  Perhaps this was 
unanticipated and unprogrammed, or maybe it was the vibe.  Whatever, he 
threw down some of the sweetest house with some very old school favorites 
and kept us all on the floor.  When the lights went up at four Jesse kept 
on going, as did the dancers.  The crew were taking down the monitors, but 
the management put them back up and he continued spinning for an extra half 
hour.  The house is in his heart and he showed it.  Respect.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_25680664==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6

Beautiful post and great insights on house music. DJ Pierre rules!

On Sat, 30 Aug 2003, Apollo wrote:

> I had been looking forward to Club 6's "House of Legends 4.0" event for
> weeks.  Hell, just about any event at Club 6 these days is a guaranteed
> good evening for me:  friendly staff;  free and non-judgmental space;
> underground vibe; and an eclectic, respectful dance crowd.  Further, they
> throw some fine house music parties.  Last night's "Legends 4.0" was one of
> those rare "in the zone" evenings for me.
>
> We arrived during David Coleman and Sen-Sei's set.  Those two are
> consistently energizing performers and they got my groove going.
>
> Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of house music followed.  I've had
> ambivalent feelings about Jesse since back in the day.  But next year marks
> the 20th anniversary of the release of the first house recording, his "On
> and On." That was the beginning of a life-long passion for many of us, so I
> give him his due.  It turns me off, though, when he begins his sets these
> days with his "...here is the originator of house music" promo, as if we
> all didn't know.  Such BSP.  And I didn't really expect that much from his
> set.  Jesse was never a great DJ or, for that matter, producer.
>
> I thought the first half-hour or so of his performance was programmed and
> uninventive, but the crowd felt otherwise.  This was not the old school
> house head group I've danced with over the years.  As one of the few
> old-timers there said to me:  "I don't know any of these
> kids."  Excellent.  A genre dies without new lovers, and these people who
> had never heard most of this old school music  were jacking their bodies
> like house's first lovers two decades ago.
>
> My main reason for coming to this party, however,  was to hear DJ Pierre.
>
> DJ Pierre -- Nathaniel Jones is his given name -- is right up there with
> Larry Levan, Marshall Jefferson, Adonis and the like:  genuinely awesome
> innovators who laid the foundation for house and electronic dance music.  I
> worship the man.  While tripping on acid back in eighties Chicago he and
> some friends invented acid house while tweaking with a Roland TB303.  Acid
> house was the genre that set fire to the rave movement in the UK and then
> the states in the late eighties.
>
> If I was given a choice of the DJs I would be willing to dance to for an
> eternity on that big dance floor in the sky, it would be Larry Levan and DJ
> Pierre.  Larry, though, is forever frozen in time in my soul.  Pierre has
> evolved over time, and has been a symbol for many in the house community
> for the radical, progressive soul of house music.
>
> When Pierre moved to NYC he took acid house even further, creating a sound
> that wedded funky brass and vocals to Chicago acid:  wild-pitch.
>
> In addition to being a prolific and paradigm-busting producer, DJ Pierre is
> also a very competent DJ.  His set last night was truly amazing.  I was so
> overcome with respect and emotion when I went up behind the decks to greet
> him, that I took his hand and kissed it.  A bit over the top, I know.  But
> it was genuine and spontaneous.  And there I stayed for most of his set,
> right behind the decks,  dancing joyfully, in perfect harmony with the
> universe, totally happy.  One cherishes times like these.  Doesn't get much
> better....
>
> Vince Lawrence didn't show, for whatever reason, so Jesse took over the
> decks after Pierre's extended set.  Jesse was wonderful.  Perhaps this was
> unanticipated and unprogrammed, or maybe it was the vibe.  Whatever, he
> threw down some of the sweetest house with some very old school favorites
> and kept us all on the floor.  When the lights went up at four Jesse kept
> on going, as did the dancers.  The crew were taking down the monitors, but
> the management put them back up and he continued spinning for an extra half
> hour.  The house is in his heart and he showed it.  Respect.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
>
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron

> -Dizzy Gillespie

Sunday, September 21, 2003 ** Progression with guest dj's Macadio &
illiaster **

RESIDENT DJ'S -- DJ JACK TRIUMPH (enuriye, KZSU Radio, Frisky Radio, Qo=F6l=
)
DJ MIKE WARD (enuriye, BoardStock, Paragon Lounge), SEPTEMBER GUEST DJ'S
-- illiaster (Stargaze, Butterzone, SNDJ), DJ Macadio. pro=B7gres=B7sion n.
The process of progressing; progress.  Movement from one member of a
continuous series to the next.  A continuous series; a sequence. As unique
as the progressive genre itself, enuriye productions launches
'Progression'. This is an exclusive Sunday experience that will entail
some serious tribal/progressive madness rocking the decks at one of the
best, most intimate venues in San Francisco: 26 Mix. This is your personal
invitation to participate in a hyper-sensory experience built around sound
and dance. We are putting out a call for the masses to join our party, a
temporal community where an attitude of acceptance, comradery and freedom
prevails. This is the beginning of our underground movement, with its
roots founded on electronic music and our personal desire to expose it to
everyone. Join our family and experience what an awesome year it has been
musically for our DJ=92s of this up-and-coming progressive collective. Ever=
y
3rd Sunday of the Month. 26 MIX 3024 MISSION STREET SAN FRANCISCO CA.

Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] .: Tonight! : Dirtbox Radio : R3 Takeover : INFAMOUS AFTERHOURS :.


Mmm Hmm.

Yes yes, it's Sunday again, and time for another installment of ze Dirtbox
Radiooooo...  Tonight's our last crew takeover (for now), featuring VA's
own Runnin Riddum Recordings - aka R3.  These cats are gonna be holding
down the fort for 5 hours, featuring a mixture of styles of jungle.  And,
as always, Dirtbox Afterhours will be kickin with ODJ and some surprise
guests.  Jerel may or may not be comin' down, depending on the price of
rice in China.

Ok, enough waffle.  Here are the timeslots and links to better serve you
and enhance your Dirtboxin' pleazure:

07-12am EST - Runnin Riddum Recordings (R3) Crew Takeover
12-??am EST - Dirtbox Afterhours wif ODJ & Some Scallywags

64k audio - http://jungletrain.net/64kbps.pls
24k audio - http://jungletrain.net/24kbps.pls
webcam - http://glue.umd.edu/~odjallen/dirtboxradio/webcam.html

Cos of some issues with their Colo, Jungletrain's site is down right now.
All streams are still fully operational, and so is the chat.  Just point
your favorite IRC client ( http://www.mirc.com for windows ) to
irc.jungletrain.net, and connect to #jungletrain.  Plus you non-nerds can
reach us on AIM at DIRTBOXRADIO.

As always, Dirtbox Radio is accepting demos from anyone who'd like to come
and play DNB, Breaks, or Hip-Hop on the show.  Just holla@dirtboxradio.com
and send us a link to an MP3, RM, WAV, OGG, or mail us a CD, MD, or good
ol' Tape.  We also like to hear new tracks, so send those fuckers as well.

Upcumming shows:
September 7th - Breaks Nite Iv - Matt Sinne, Ikarus F, Bioteknik
September 14th - Scathe
September 21st - 2Tuff Crew (Email's comin, Andy)
September 28th - Mugzy, Decepticon, Abe Froman

So that's about it.  For up-to-date info, lineups, Kru bios, and the
infamous Archives, hit up our website at http://www.dirtboxradio.com

We just upgraded our line, too... so you'll be downloading faster:-D

Easy,
Jackson (ODJ)
Partners in Crime, Dirtbox Radio, Trividual Productions, ALIAS

From: "Andrew Phelan" <vgsandrew@hotmail.com>

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1106
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
Message-ID: <Law14-OE33EfEj9YUML000137bd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 31 Aug 2003 23:11:03.0929 (UTC) FILETIME=[26839E90:01C37015]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6

Unfortunately I didn't attend this event because of false advertising on the
Club Six email list.  The party was listed as $10 after 11pm, and they were
charging $15.  I'm sick of the bullshit I've been dealing with at clubs
recently, including:  All night guestlists switched to "before 11"
guestlists without notice on the night of the event, promoters who confirm
that you're on the guestlist but don't put you on, flyers and email lists
with no pricing information, flyers and email lists with false pricing
information, and on and on.  The older I get, the more I realize that
promoters who have their shit together in this scene are the exception
rather than the rule.  I didn't attend the event because I refuse to be
suckered into going to a night and then have the price jacked up on me.

Tonight it's off to see Derrick Carter at Sno-Drift: last time I went there
to see him the speakers on the right side of the room were shorting on and
off the whole night and I had a number of friends on the guestlist who
didn't get in.  It's unfortunate the underground rarely pulls any out of
town house names with any talent, so it's off to fluffy money land once
again...

-Andrew

----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Saturday, August 30, 2003 6:06 PM
Subject: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6


> I had been looking forward to Club 6's "House of Legends 4.0" event for
> weeks.  Hell, just about any event at Club 6 these days is a guaranteed
> good evening for me:  friendly staff;  free and non-judgmental space;
> underground vibe; and an eclectic, respectful dance crowd.  Further, they
> throw some fine house music parties.  Last night's "Legends 4.0" was one
of
> those rare "in the zone" evenings for me.
>
> We arrived during David Coleman and Sen-Sei's set.  Those two are
> consistently energizing performers and they got my groove going.
>
> Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of house music followed.  I've had
> ambivalent feelings about Jesse since back in the day.  But next year
marks
> the 20th anniversary of the release of the first house recording, his "On
> and On." That was the beginning of a life-long passion for many of us, so
I
> give him his due.  It turns me off, though, when he begins his sets these
> days with his "...here is the originator of house music" promo, as if we
> all didn't know.  Such BSP.  And I didn't really expect that much from his
> set.  Jesse was never a great DJ or, for that matter, producer.
>
> I thought the first half-hour or so of his performance was programmed and
> uninventive, but the crowd felt otherwise.  This was not the old school
> house head group I've danced with over the years.  As one of the few
> old-timers there said to me:  "I don't know any of these
> kids."  Excellent.  A genre dies without new lovers, and these people who
> had never heard most of this old school music  were jacking their bodies
> like house's first lovers two decades ago.
>
> My main reason for coming to this party, however,  was to hear DJ Pierre.
>
> DJ Pierre -- Nathaniel Jones is his given name -- is right up there with
> Larry Levan, Marshall Jefferson, Adonis and the like:  genuinely awesome
> innovators who laid the foundation for house and electronic dance music.
I
> worship the man.  While tripping on acid back in eighties Chicago he and
> some friends invented acid house while tweaking with a Roland TB303.  Acid
> house was the genre that set fire to the rave movement in the UK and then
> the states in the late eighties.
>
> If I was given a choice of the DJs I would be willing to dance to for an
> eternity on that big dance floor in the sky, it would be Larry Levan and
DJ
> Pierre.  Larry, though, is forever frozen in time in my soul.  Pierre has
> evolved over time, and has been a symbol for many in the house community
> for the radical, progressive soul of house music.
>
> When Pierre moved to NYC he took acid house even further, creating a sound
> that wedded funky brass and vocals to Chicago acid:  wild-pitch.
>
> In addition to being a prolific and paradigm-busting producer, DJ Pierre
is
> also a very competent DJ.  His set last night was truly amazing.  I was so
> overcome with respect and emotion when I went up behind the decks to greet
> him, that I took his hand and kissed it.  A bit over the top, I know.  But
> it was genuine and spontaneous.  And there I stayed for most of his set,
> right behind the decks,  dancing joyfully, in perfect harmony with the
> universe, totally happy.  One cherishes times like these.  Doesn't get
much
> better....
>
> Vince Lawrence didn't show, for whatever reason, so Jesse took over the
> decks after Pierre's extended set.  Jesse was wonderful.  Perhaps this was
> unanticipated and unprogrammed, or maybe it was the vibe.  Whatever, he
> threw down some of the sweetest house with some very old school favorites
> and kept us all on the floor.  When the lights went up at four Jesse kept
> on going, as did the dancers.  The crew were taking down the monitors, but
> the management put them back up and he continued spinning for an extra
half
> hour.  The house is in his heart and he showed it.  Respect.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
>
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
It's
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well
can
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when
we
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron
>
> "It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
> -Dizzy Gillespie
>
> U

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 04:11 PM 8/31/2003 -0700, Andrew Phelan wrote:

>Unfortunately I didn't attend this event because of false advertising on the
>Club Six email list.  The party was listed as $10 after 11pm, and they were
>charging $15.  I'm sick of the bullshit I've been dealing with at clubs
>recently, including:  All night guestlists switched to "before 11"
>guestlists without notice on the night of the event, promoters who confirm
>that you're on the guestlist but don't put you on, flyers and email lists
>with no pricing information, flyers and email lists with false pricing
>information, and on and on.  The older I get, the more I realize that
>promoters who have their shit together in this scene are the exception
>rather than the rule.  I didn't attend the event because I refuse to be
>suckered into going to a night and then have the price jacked up on me.

I downloaded and printed the flier from Club 6's website 
--   www.clubsix1.com  --and it clearly states on both sides that the cost 
is $10.00 before 11 PM.

Personally, I don't go to many clubs these days because I don't like being 
treated as a criminal, both at the door and inside.  It's either ug parties 
these days or Club 6, where I am treated with respect.


>Tonight it's off to see Derrick Carter at Sno-Drift: last time I went there
>to see him the speakers on the right side of the room were shorting on and
>off the whole night and I had a number of friends on the guestlist who
>didn't get in.  It's unfortunate the underground rarely pulls any out of
>town house names with any talent, so it's off to fluffy money land once
>again...

We are also on the guest list at the Sno-Drift tonight, but after our last 
experience at Sno-Drift I'm going to pass.  Six of us were on 12 Monkeys 
guest list for Derrick Carter the last time he performed there.  When we 
got to the venue we were treated with much disrespect.  No guest list could 
be found with our names on it.  Now, I rarely accept "guest list" 
privileges for my own reasons.  But I was much troubled that my friends' 
evening was destroyed.  I gave 12 Monkeys a lashing both privately and 
publicly.  Then I discovered after asking around in the community that it 
was not the promoter here, but the management of Sno-Drift that were to 
blame.  Seems they regularly "lose" the promoter's guest list and push 
those on such lists to buy at the door with the promise (never kept) that 
somehow this can all be corrected at the end of the evening.

Screw me once, it's your karma;  twice and I'm the fool.

My own feeling is that promoters and club managers should experience their 
parties and venues as paying guests at least once a month (and I don't care 
if one has to go in disguise).  How do you feel to be patted down;  screwed 
out of money at the door;  have your drinks taken before you're 
finished;  have security flash lights in your eyes in the venue;      be 
packed into a room with 800 peeps when only 500 can fit comfortably;  stand 
in the rain for an hour to get in (?)....and so on.

Love,

Apollo

>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

Subject: Re: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6

Angel is a friend of mine, but I'm going to paste in an email I recieved on
one of my spam accounts clearly listing the party as $10 at the end of one
of the worst formatted emails I've ever recieved.  I've been screwed too
many times recently to chalk something up as a " honest mistake" anymore,
even though I know sometimes it is:

            Subj: Legends of House
            Date: 8/25/2003 7:12:20 PM Pacific Standard Time
            From: clubsix@xmr3.com
            To: andrewphe@aol.com
            Sent from the Internet (Details)



Legends of House @ SIX!
Friday, August 29th: "Legends of House". The fourth Installment of Legends
include The Godfather of Acid House, DJ Pierre(Chicago), The Founder of
Chicago based House Music Label Trax Records, Vince Lawrence(Chicago), The
Originator of House Music Jesse Saunders(Chicago).  As always with The
Legends of House Series, this is the first time ever this trio has played
together. This Legends show will also include the Record Release Party for
Jesse Saunders newest Release "Everybody"(Broken Records/King Street
Records). These Legends will be joined by the San Francisco based duo of
Sen-Sei and David Coleman(Kinetic Grooves/Thumpradio/ Atwater Synicate).That
same evening Legends 4.0 welcomes a special Sister SF presentation in the
Lounge with Polywog, DJ ELZ and DJ Aura.
DJ Pierre(Chicago) - DJ/Producer/Artist/Remixer. As one of the founders of
Acid House and a member of Phuture he recorded the seminal "Acid Trax". He
is world famous for his "Wild Pitch" sound. Pierre is the creator of such
dance classics like "The Horn Song", "Everybody Dance", "String Free", and
has 100's of credits in his catalogue using a multiple of names and groups.
Pierre has toured the world with his trademark DJ style which encompasses
everything form early Chicago Acid and Detroit Techno to current garage and
hard House. DJ Pierre is recognized worldwide as the Godfather of Acid
House. Catch Pierre's latest Release "I'm a Freak" on Drum Records. It's our
honor to have Pierre grace our decks in this very rare SF appearance.
Vince Lawrence(Chicago) - DJ/Producer/Lyricist. Vince Lawrence is an
internationally recognized innovator in dance music. Industry insiders
recognize Vince as co-author of the first recording officially designated
"House Music". Created with the initial organization of Trax Records, a
seminal Chicago House label. Lawrence has exposed some of the dance world's
greatest prodigies, including Marshall Jefferson(Move your Body, Ride the
Rhythm, etc), Adonis, Byron Styngly, Farley Jackmaster Funk, Ron Hardy,
Screamin' Rachel and Jesse Saunders while inspiring many others.
Jesse Saunders(Chicago) - is the architect of the musical style known as
"House Music". He wrote. Produced and released the first documented House
record titles "On & On" through his own label Jes Say Records. His next hitz
"Funk U Up" "Real Love" and the platinum selling single "Love Can't Turn
Around" served as the foundation for a funky and soulful new sound in
electronic music. Jesse Saunders reigns as the ambassador for the global
house craze through his work as a DJ, producer, filmmaker and author. After
a lifetime of influential and innovative work, Jesse Saunders continues to
break new ground. 2003 marks the beginning of his legacy. "On & On" was
created and conceived in the summer of 1983, and 2003 will mark the 20th
anniversary and re-release of the world's most famous and enduring House
record. A world tour is in the making and it won't stop until 2004! There is
a special documentary that will be released with the original tracks as well
as remixes on Enhanced CD, DVD, and the audio will be available on vinyl as
well.
FREE ADMISSION* (On Friday August 29th) for you and up to SIX of your
friends for Legends of House 4.0 with DJ Pierre(The Godfather Of Acid
House), Jesse Saunders(The Originator of House), Vince Lawerence(The Founder
of Trax Records),Polywog, DJ ELZ, and DJ Aura.
Simply RSVP (clubsix5@yahoo.com) by Midnight Thursday August 28th and you
and up to SIX of your friends can see Legends 4.0 for FREE. We must receive
everyone full names(First and Last) along with their email addresses for
FREE Admission. All guests must arrive by 10:30pm (No Exceptions).
All RSVP'S must be received @ clubsix5@yahoo.com. Time: 9 pm - 4 am.
Admission: $5 before 10 pm, $10 after, 21+.

Regards,
Angel
Club Six
60 Sixth Street
(Between Market & Mission on the corner of Jessie Alley)
San Francisco, CA 94103
415.863.1221 415.531.6593
-------------------------------------------
If you would prefer not to receive further messages from this sender, please
click on the following Internet link and confirm your request:
http://www.xmr3.com/rm/731244-15065820-2-10323-US1-B983/andrewphe@aol.com/HC
SA4C2
You will receive one additional e-mail message confirming your removal.

> experience at Sno-Drift I'm going to pass.  Six of us were on 12 Monkeys
> guest list for Derrick Carter the last time he performed there.  When we
> got to the venue we were treated with much disrespect.  No guest list
could
> be found with our names on it.  Now, I rarely accept "guest list"
> privileges for my own reasons.  But I was much troubled that my friends'
> evening was destroyed.  I gave 12 Monkeys a lashing both privately and
> publicly.  Then I discovered after asking around in the community that it
> was not the promoter here, but the management of Sno-Drift that were to
> blame.  Seems they regularly "lose" the promoter's guest list and push
> those on such lists to buy at the door with the promise (never kept) that
> somehow this can all be corrected at the end of the evening.
>
> Screw me once, it's your karma;  twice and I'm the fool.
>
> My own feeling is that promoters and club managers should experience their
> parties and venues as paying guests at least once a month (and I don't
care
> if one has to go in disguise).  How do you feel to be patted down;
screwed
> out of money at the door;  have your drinks taken before you're
> finished;  have security flash lights in your eyes in the venue;      be
> packed into a room with 800 peeps when only 500 can fit comfortably;
stand
> in the rain for an hour to get in (?)....and so on.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
> >----- Original Message -----
> >From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> >To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> >Sent: Saturday, August 30, 2003 6:06 PM
> >Subject: [sfraves] House of Legends 4.0 at Club 6
> >
> >
> > > I had been looking forward to Club 6's "House of Legends 4.0" event
for
> > > weeks.  Hell, just about any event at Club 6 these days is a
guaranteed
> > > good evening for me:  friendly staff;  free and non-judgmental space;
> > > underground vibe; and an eclectic, respectful dance crowd.  Further,
they
> > > throw some fine house music parties.  Last night's "Legends 4.0" was
one
> >of
> > > those rare "in the zone" evenings for me.
> > >
> > > We arrived during David Coleman and Sen-Sei's set.  Those two are
> > > consistently energizing performers and they got my groove going.
> > >
> > > Jesse Saunders, the "originator" of house music followed.  I've had
> > > ambivalent feelings about Jesse since back in the day.  But next year
> >marks
> > > the 20th anniversary of the release of the first house recording, his
"On
> > > and On." That was the beginning of a life-long passion for many of us,
so
> >I
> > > give him his due.  It turns me off, though, when he begins his sets
these
> > > days with his "...here is the originator of house music" promo, as if
we
> > > all didn't know.  Such BSP.  And I didn't really expect that much from
his
> > > set.  Jesse was never a great DJ or, for that matter, producer.
> > >
> > > I thought the first half-hour or so of his performance was programmed
and
> > > uninventive, but the crowd felt otherwise.  This was not the old
school
> > > house head group I've danced with over the years.  As one of the few
> > > old-timers there said to me:  "I don't know any of these
> > > kids."  Excellent.  A genre dies without new lovers, and these people
who
> > > had never heard most of this old school music  were jacking their
bodies
> > > like house's first lovers two decades ago.
> > >
> > > My main reason for coming to this party, however,  was to hear DJ
Pierre.
> > >
> > > DJ Pierre -- Nathaniel Jones is his given name -- is right up there
with
> > > Larry Levan, Marshall Jefferson, Adonis and the like:  genuinely
awesome
> > > innovators who laid the foundation for house and electronic dance
music.
> >I
> > > worship the man.  While tripping on acid back in eighties Chicago he
and
> > > some friends invented acid house while tweaking with a Roland TB303.
Acid
> > > house was the genre that set fire to the rave movement in the UK and
then
> > > the states in the late eighties.
> > >
> > > If I was given a choice of the DJs I would be willing to dance to for
an
> > > eternity on that big dance floor in the sky, it would be Larry Levan
and
> >DJ
> > > Pierre.  Larry, though, is forever frozen in time in my soul.  Pierre
has
> > > evolved over time, and has been a symbol for many in the house
community
> > > for the radical, progressive soul of house music.
> > >
> > > When Pierre moved to NYC he took acid house even further, creating a
sound
> > > that wedded funky brass and vocals to Chicago acid:  wild-pitch.
> > >
> > > In addition to being a prolific and paradigm-busting producer, DJ
Pierre
> >is
> > > also a very competent DJ.  His set last night was truly amazing.  I
was so
> > > overcome with respect and emotion when I went up behind the decks to
greet
> > > him, that I took his hand and kissed it.  A bit over the top, I know.
But
> > > it was genuine and spontaneous.  And there I stayed for most of his
set,
> > > right behind the decks,  dancing joyfully, in perfect harmony with the
> > > universe, totally happy.  One cherishes times like these.  Doesn't get
> >much
> > > better....
> > >
> > > Vince Lawrence didn't show, for whatever reason, so Jesse took over
the
> > > decks after Pierre's extended set.  Jesse was wonderful.  Perhaps this
was
> > > unanticipated and unprogrammed, or maybe it was the vibe.  Whatever,
he
> > > threw down some of the sweetest house with some very old school
favorites
> > > and kept us all on the floor.  When the lights went up at four Jesse
kept
> > > on going, as did the dancers.  The crew were taking down the monitors,
but
> > > the management put them back up and he continued spinning for an extra
> >half
> > > hour.  The house is in his heart and he showed it.  Respect.
> > >
> > > Love,
> > >
> > > Apollo
> > >
> > > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
> > >
> > > House Music 101:
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> > >

do
> > > the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is
no
> > > safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
> > > adventure or nothing."
> > > -Helen Keller
> > >
> > > "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
> >It's
> > > a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness
well
> >can
> > > we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real
when
> >we
> > > recognize our shared humanity."
> > > -Pema Chodron
> > >
> > > "It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
> > > -Dizzy Gillespie
